title: Provision of strengthened Security Operations in support of Humanitarian work in Mogadishu, Somalia.
description:
UNDSS enables all Humanitarian activities to take place in Somalia. This project seeks US $ 250,000 to meet staff costs of a Security Operations Officer (SOO) on P3 International level, Temporary Appointment Contract for a period of 12 Months. These funds will cover Salary for 12 months amp associated, Accommodation fees for 12 months and associated costs including Communications and stationery for a period of one year. The project seeks to achieve uninterrupted security operations by enhancing the capacity of the operations Centre and facilitating day-to day operations of support Humanitarian agencies in Mogadishu.

The Security Operations Officer carries among others, the following important functions. Provision of Security Information to the Principal Security Advisor (PSA) and Deputy Security Advisor (DSA) for updates in Somalia Security cell, The SOO is the focal point on all security briefings an updates in areas of jurisdiction. The officer is mandated to issue security clearances to Humanitarians seeking access in the region covered. S/he chairs security coordination meetings and maintains security matrix for updates to the PSA and DSA.

The functions of a Security Operation officer include among others:- issuing security clearance to Humanitarians accessing the area of jurisdiction, as security focal point, the SOO briefs the Principal Security Advisor (PSA) and Deputy Security Advisor (DSA) on security situation for updates in the Somalia Security Cell the Officer maintains a matrix of security incidents in areas of responsibility, offers security briefings, conducts security mission assessments, shares information on security matters and supervising Local Security Advisors (LSAs). The SOOs support Humanitarian Agencies by offering escorts during missions using Armoured vehicles and other Personal Protective Equipment.

title: Maternity Clinic and Training Project
description:
Long-running conflict has destroyed the infrastructure of the Somali state and the country has one of the worst health indicators in the world. The high-risk groups are 2.4 million children under age 5 and more than 3 million women of child-bearing age. Ac
cording to WHO the maternal mortality ratio is 732 per 100 000 live births although most of the maternal deaths would be preventable. Rebuilding the health sector is challenged by a shortage of professional staff financial resources and effective governanc
e and NGOs have played a key role in providing with these services. African Care?s Maternity Clinic and Training project has since its start in 2012 supported the development of the FinSom maternity clinic together with the local partner VMDSO. Results sho
w that the service of the clinic has decreased maternal mortality rate prevalence of tetanus raised awareness about exclusive breast feeding and FGM. The clinic is well-known in Afgoye and surrounding areas and a vital source of quality maternal health car
e for both expectant mothers and the community. Hence the maternal health care services are continued also in the continuation phase of the project.The project at hand seeks to further enhance the capacity and services of the partner and the clinic so that
 eventually maternal health services could be provided without development cooperation funding. This is done by investing in the education and training of the VMDSO staff and health workers and monitoring the long-term impact of the trainings. Simultaneous
ly invaluable information on the key challenges and development needs will be mapped out and used for future trainings.  Also the support of the sexual violence victims will be intensified. It will be expanded to an in-person counselling in addition to the
 telephone support. Open-access seminars and family counselling are likewise continued and further intensified. Seminars about gender equality family planning and gender-based violence work to dismantle unequal social structures through open dialogue. Proj
ect's beneficiaries are women in labour children victims of sexual violence clinic?s personnel and partner organization VMDSO.

title: Sahansaho ? against desertification in Somalia
description:
The key development problem which the project aims to find solutions to is the desertification leading to lack of livelihoods poverty and forced migration. The objective is sustainable use of natural resources and secured livelihood in the project areas. T
he project started in 2012 and it has been planned for 10 years. This continuation project will be its 4th and final phase.The outcomes of 2019-2022 will be:1. Environmental centers developed into regional hubs2. Educational institutions and trainers have 
expertise to provide environmental education3. Resilience of local communities to climate change and drought improved4. Implementation of policies related to natural resource management (NRM)The outputs will be: 1.1. Seedlings of locally successful species
 produced planted distributed and sold per year 1.2. Seed collection stands established and local availability of the seeds of the most important species secured 1.3. Operating models for the environmental centers developed 2.1. Trainers trained and traini
ng material produced 2.2. Training materials and research opportunities provided to universities and environmental education material provided to teachers 3.1. Charcoal and firewood consumption reduced in local communities 3.2. Agroforestry practices and s
oil and water conservation techniques adopted in local communities 4.1.  Network of the environmental actors built and environmental efforts and common initiatives coordinated at all project sites 4.2.  Policy reviews and briefs produced for policy dialogu
e with ministries of environment and implementation of environmental policies startedThe project is implemented at 3 sites in Somalia with the FSN's four partners in Finland and three partners in Somalia. The innovative cooperative model enforces the civil
 society in Somalia and creates new networks  that also promote peace and stability.The beneficiaries are local communities authorities and educational institutions among others.

title: Wellbeing by Green and Smart Energy
description:
The aim of the project is to develop rapidly scalable business model and technology that decreases consumer price of energy increases electricity availability and makes energy system less depending on fossil fuels.Technical commercial and social requiremen
ts and opportunities will be analysed in project feasibility study.Business plan will be done together with local specialist based on the feasibility study results. The business plan will be used also for scaling the business later on.The contact with our 
local partner Star Group for optimizing the energy efficiency and sales of green energy will be done when the business plan is ready.The pilot project includes delivery of 70kW solar power plant 70kVA Dynamic Power System that monitors and controls energy 
efficiency and inverts solar power and more than 100kWh Lithium-Ion energy storage capacity. Especial Blockchain based control and invoicing system will be developed and several power meters will be installed for monitoring and sales of energy. Cleaner Fut
ure Oy and Nordic ST Engineering and Consulting Oy will establish a daughter company in Somaliland to operate the pilot plant. The operation of the daughter company will be expanded based on the pilot project experiences.The piloting verifies our way of co
upling different technologies taking into account especial conditionsn and needs in the target country. The technology and business model is rapidly scalable in other African countries as well. Local staff will be trained to build install and operate the p
ilot system. Trained personnel will be hired to expand the operations when scaling the business. The project leads to increased economic activity improves the local living conditions and decreases dependency from fossil fuels.

programming: Nordic ST Engineering and Consulting Oy

title: FCA: Supporting national and local level reconciliation in Somalia
description:
Somalia is recovering from decades of war and collapse of state structures. The core state functions are now operating and state formation is underway. The legitimacy of the state however is still weak. Conflicts and violence remain a significant challenge
. The biggest threat is still Al Shabaab but violent conflicts between clans and militias as well as organized crime are also common. The weak security situation hampers development efforts and attempts to address the difficult humanitarian situation.Finn 
Church Aid (FCA) and the Network for Religious and Traditional Peacemakers have been active in mediation and local-level democratisation and institution building in Somalia for several years. In 2017 an expert was seconded to the Ministry for Interior Fede
ral Affairs and Reconciliation (MoIFAR) at the request of the Somali government. The expert has held a key position in the team in charge of drafting the strategy for reconciliation. During the years 2018-2019 the Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland ha
s supported national and local-level reconciliation processes through FCA and the Network. The first phase of the project saw the development of a nation-wide National Reconciliation Framework based on consultations with state and civil society actors. In 
February 2019 the draft was validated at a national conference in Mogadishu. Altogether 300 representatives from the federal government federal member states and civil society took part in the conference. The National Reconciliation Framework was approved 
by the Cabinet in in March 2019. It has become one of the key priorities of the Somali government and especially MoIFAR.The second phase of the project supports MoIFAR in the implementation of the national reconciliation process while advancing the partici
pation of women and youth in the process. The project also includes support to local-level reconciliation. Finland supports the second phase of the project with 461 384 euros. The project will be implemented over a period of 12 months in 2019-2020.

title: Mustaqbaldoon
description:
The project contributes to the development problem of the vulnerability of the youth which is manifested in youth unemployment and limited access to income causing risky survival strategies such as informal quasi-legal or illegal activities and as a conseq
uence social problems like violence early sexual activity and a range of economic physical and psychological risks.The principal outcomes of the project are 1) Strengthened Civil Society and Local Administration 2) Increased motivation of youth to contribu
te to the society and 3) Increased economic empowerment of youth. The central activities include capacitating the local CSOs and public administration turning the risky survival strategies of youth to healthy ones and 3) training youth to recognize local i
ncome generation opportunities instead of leaving the country.  Developing countries? own economies have generated more jobs livelihood opportunities and well-being is the priority area of Finland's development policy the project is aimed at contributing t
o. Somalia is ranked as one of the bottom five countries in terms of gender inequality and therefore positive discrimination and affirmative measures will be taken to enhance the participation of young women and girls and to raise awareness about their par
ticular needs. The project aims to reduce inequality by emphasizing the rights of all youth as full and equal members of the communities where they live. Project respects climate sustainability too.The project capacitates CSOs and public administration to 
work with private sector according to multi-stakeholder approach. Helsinki Deaconess Institute?s Vamos services is acknowledged in a national level as a unique concept to support vulnerable youth's access to education and employment. The same concept will 
be used together with cooperation partners Y-PEER in Hargeisa and Gedo Development in Gedo. The principal beneficiaries of the project are the youth (15-35 years) who have dropped out from education and employment.

title: Human rights based approach to strengthening community mental health services in Somaliland
description:
The project tackles Somaliland's high burden of mental health problems coupled with a weak mental health care infrastructure which is not able to provide high-quality mental health services from a human rights perspective.The project aims to increase the a
ccess of people to community-based mental health services;promote the adoption of a human rights based approach to mental health in public/private mental health services;and to increase public awareness on mental health issues to decrease the stigma and di
scrimination against people with mental disorders in Somaliland.A special focus is on women/girls and vulnerable groups (SGBV survivorsIDPsdisabled personsprisoners).To support the sustainability of the intervention and to promote the long-term development
 of the mental health care infrastructure in Somalilandthe project will increase the capacity of health care officials to promote mental health from a human rights perspective to coordinate mental health services.The main cross-cutting themes of the projec
t are:health promotionhuman rightsgender equality and good governance.The main activities are: training community mental health workers and social workers to provide community mental health servicesprovision of out-patient treatmentsupporting the capacity 
of the MOH to plan and implement mental health services and policyand raising awareness on mental health.The main beneficiaries of the project are people in Somaliland suffering from mental disorderstheir families and communitiesvulnerable groups in need o
f mental health care civil society and health officials.PSR is well positioned to carry out the project with 30+ years of experience in health development projects also of mental health projects in post-conflict contexts.PSR has long-term project experienc
e in Somalia/Somaliland (2006-) and good local networks.The local partner GAVO is a well-respected local NGO with long-term experience in mental health projects.The Finnish partners FiPSR and Disability Partnership Finland have long-term experience that co
ntributes closely to the project.The project contributes to the FSA project in Jubaland and collaborates with the HDI project in Somaliland

title: Fighting TB in Somalia: public-private partnerships and inclusive communities
description:
The project is founded on PSR's previous projects in Somalia which have developed new strategies to tackle tuberculosis (TB) ? especially in community and private sector engagement. A special focus will be placed on women and vulnerable community members: 
disabled persons IDPs and prisoners. Tuberculosis is a central health problem in Somalia. The increase of multi-drug resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) is a global threat ? fighting against MDR-TB in Somalia benefits all countries. Another central problem is 
the low treatment coverage rate of about 37% leaving far too many cases untreated further transmitting tuberculosis to others. The impact targets of the project are to: a) tackle multi-drug resistant tuberculosis; and b) increase the tuberculosis case dete
ction rate. The long-term objective of the project is to contribute to the reduction of the tuberculosis burden in Somalia with the following means:1. Increase the access of women and vulnerable groups to TB services (such as disabled personsIDPs and priso
ners)2. Increase TB referrals from the private sector3. Improve the quality of TB treatment in both the public and private sector4. Improve the quality of TB laboratory work.The central partners of the project are the National Tuberculosis Programmes of So
maliland and Somalia. PSR has a central role in developing the national tuberculosis diagnostic infrastructure in Somalia. The project will support the National TB Reference Laboratories in Somaliland and South-Central Somalia as well as will treatment of 
tuberculosis patients in 3 clinics in Hargeisa and Mogadishu. These clinics will develop innovative community public and private sector engagement models to increase case detection improve treatment quality and to increase public awareness and decrease sti
gma/discrimination. The clinics will also provide HIV services and nutritional support for malnourished patients (with WFP).Together with the local administration the tuberculosis clinics will be transformed into health centers providing specialized tuberc
ulosis services by the end of 2022 to support integration with basic health services and sustainability after the project has ended.

title: Mobile Health Clinic - Daryeel Project in Somalia Afmadow
description:
The Daryeel Mobile Health Clinic ?project aims at providing preventive and basic health care services to rural areas outside of Afmadow town in Jubaland Somalia. The project is executed by the Finland-Somalia Association (FSA) with partner NGO SAHDA and th
e Jubaland Ministry of Health. The project is a continuation of the Maternal and Child Health Services Clinic ?project that the FSA has ran since 2011 in Afmadow town. Based on an agreement with the Jubaland Ministry of Health the FSA has been asked to swi
tch its foces to more remote villages through a mobile clinic. The mobile clinic is to start its operations in 2018 depending on permission from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Finland. With this application the project plan is to continue the Mobile He
alth Clinic through 2019-2020 a total of three years.The main development problem that the project aims to solve is the poor access to preventive and basic health care in the Afmadow area in Jubaland Somalia. The project aims to take health services close 
to remote communities where it is difficult to get access to basic healthcare and where travelling is a challenge. By curing and providing basic health services in remote locations the project contrib-utes to creating a healthier community and society with
 people who are able to work for their own livelihoods. In this context the project contributes significantly to achieving the UN?s Sustainable Development Goals. The development impact that the project strives for is to increase the wellbeing of the commu
nities in the project area and to decrease the number of diseases and illnesses.The mobile clinic concept includes three core outputs:1. Supporting existing healthcare by providing health services in suburbs nearby villages and towns2. Providing supportive
 services in first aid family reproductive services and interventions reducing infectious diseases in the target villages3. Reducing travelling for health services from the towns as well as building the competence of the local community in health particula
rly by giving tools and knowledge to local midwives.

title: Piloting and implementation of PPA business model
description:
This specific Finnpartnership project is intended to pilot the PPA business model for SLA's first customer deliveries with this business model. This pilot project will serve as a business validation project and as a reference for the following clients and 
financiers who will need to be in quickly after the first project in order to grow the business. Because of the importance of the project the customers and the target have been selected with care and also the price of electricity and hence the portability 
of the project has been somewhat tinged to the normal target level in order to remain customer relationship good and stable.The main customer of the pilot project is Barbara Cafe Hargeisa's Deero Mall. The owner of the client is SLA's long-time acquaintanc
e the owner of the customer business has also helped SLA in business development so it is expected that the customer relationship will be working. In addition electricity will be sold at least to the FlyDubai Hargeisa office (Emirates airline low cost airl
ine that also fly between Helsinki and Dubai) ans several other outlets in located in the same mall.The system itself is a 100 kW (DC) / 90 kW (AC) photovoltaic system (100 kWp panel power and 90 kW inverter power) with 221 kWh battery capacity (16 x 13.8 
kWh BYD batteries). There is more demand for electricity in the mall but the size of the project is currently limited by a roof area that does not allow a larger number of solar panels. The investment cost of the entire physical system (iron) including log
istics customs local transport installations etc. is approximately USD 206000. In addition the launch of the PPA business requires an enterprise resource planning system enabling remote reading control mobile payment etc. which will also cost USD 27000. Th
e system generates about 178000 kWh of electricity annually of which approximately 70000 kWh is sold to Barbara Cafe and the remaining approximately 110000 kWh sold to other shopping mall users already discussed and because the price of electricity from ot
her customers is remarkably high it is clear that all electricity can be sold. Negotiations for other PPAs are ongoing.

title: Pilot project: Wellbeing by Green and Smart Energy
description:
The aim of the project is to develop rapidly scalable business model and technology that decreases consumer price of energy increases electricity availability and makes energy system less depending on fossil fuels.Technical commercial and social requiremen
ts and opportunities are already analysed in project feasibility study.Business plan will be done together with local specialist based on the feasibility study and piloting results. The business plan will be used also for scaling the business later on.The 
place of installation is already checked and approved during feasibility study phase.The pilot project includes delivery of 20-30kW solar power plant 35-70kVA Dynamic Power System that monitors and controls energy efficiency and inverts solar power and nec
essary amount of energy storage capacity. Especial Blockchain-based control and invoicing system will be developed and several power meters will be installed for monitoring and creating technical platform for the sales of energy. Cleaner Future Oy and Nord
ic ST Engineering and Consulting Oy have already established a company in Somaliland to operate the pilot plant. Real commercial operation of the company will be started after successful operation of the pilot project.The piloting verifies our way of coupl
ing different technologies taking into account especial conditionsn and needs in the target country. The technology and business model is rapidly scalable in other African countries as well. Local staff will be trained to build install and operate the pilo
t system. Trained personnel will be hired to expand the operations when scaling the business. The project leads to increased economic activity improves the local living conditions and decreases dependency from fossil fuels.

title: Service company for SMEs development in Fragile States
description:
FCAI aims to promote the welfare of communities in fragile contexts through investments in sustainable and resilient SME's/companies. However since the companies in fragile countries are rarely investment ready the trust between the investor and investee n
eeds to be built gradually therefore FCA will as a first step provide technical Assistance (TA) to the target companies (based on their unique needs) to enable them improve their systems. The next step is to then identify the 'gazelles' SME's/companies tha
t have shown potential in terms of both sustainability and resilience and process these companies for further financial support (investment). There are clear signs that development banks (e.g. AfDB IFC and IsDB) are open to providing TA funds for SME's in 
fragile countries and are only held back by a lack of trustworthy service providers. FCA will therefore tap into this funding by leveraging its country level infrastructure and expertise (e.g. 3 offices and over and over 25 employees in Somalia 5 Employees
 in Eritrea and 26 Employees in Jordan) to ensure sustainability of this project in the medium term with the SME's paying their way in the long term. Considering country specific activity;In Somalia Finnpartnership?s ?The Somalia Business Pilot project? is
 coming to an end and the FCA project could utilize and strengthen the already established business relations between Finnish and Somali companies and to promote business projects and investments in Somalia. In Eritrea FCA has unique position as the sole I
NGO on the ground and it will leverage its understanding of the operations environment and the existing networks with both the Government and the nascent private sector. FCA will carry out an assessment mission to Eritrea as precursor to   a more thorough 
evaluation of business environment opportunities and challenges.In Jordan FCA is already working with business boosters and will with this project seek to pilot fin-tech from Finland as a way to accelerate business formation and also identify the tools tha
t can be rolled out to other more fragile countries.

title: IOM Enhancing the Institutional Capacity of the Immigration and Naturalization Directorate of Somalia
description:
Somalia is recovering from decades of war and collapse of state structures. The core state functions are now recovering but the legitimacy and capacity of the state are still weak. Conflicts and violence remain a significant challenge. The prolonged confli
ct has resulted in porous air sea and land-border management providing a thriving conduit for Transnational organized immigration crimes. In order to improve security and strengthen state legitimacy the Federal Government of Somalia is aiming at strengthen
ing the capacity of the Immigration and Naturalisation Directorate IND in line with the National Development Plan. The project will focus on developing the institutional capacity of IND especially its HR Department in order to strengthen the legitimacy of 
the Federal Government of Somalia in the field of immigration and border management. The project will utilize diaspora and international experts in developing capacity and strengthen IND?s infrastructural capabilities to deliver quality public services.   
The project will be implemented by the International Organisation for Migration (IOM) during a period of 14 months in 2020 - 2021. Finland supports the project with 1 000 000 euros.

title: Somali Health and Nutrition Programme (SHINE) 2016-2021
description: Improve the health of Somalis which leads to improved human development and economic development outcomes for Somalia.

title: SAVE Community health provision
description: This intervention contributes to improve access of the Somali population to quality, affordable and equitable health services in South Central Somalia and Puntland. In a context of still very low health services coverage, high level of vulnerabilities and protracted conflict, this intervention will ensure the delivery of essential primarily health care services, focusing on women and children, while at the same time contributing to progressively build the health system at both district and regional levels.

title: World Food Programme (WFP), food assistance and cash transfers
description: Through the usage of food aid in the form of dairy products, Swiss Humanitarian Aid contributes to the prevention and treatment of malnutrition, undernourishment, and disease. The SDC’s Humanitarian Aid administers the credit granted by parliament for a yearly amount of some CHF 20 million destined for the purchase of dairy products and their use for the benefit of the needy. Its task is to ensure a sustainable, targeted, and closely monitored food aid.

title: Support to the Durable Solutions Initiative (DSI)
description: In Somalia, more than 2.6 mio people are internally displaced. Switzerland contributes to the provision of durable solutions for these people in the region by enhancing the awareness and the capacity of all relevant humanitarian, development and state-building actors under the leadership of the Somali Government. By addressing the underlying causes of protracted displacement, the affected people are offered the perspective of integration and self-reliance rather than migration.

title: UNFPA Support to Health, gender and Data
description: The maternal mortality rates in Somalia are among the highest in the world, which puts women at a high risk in and around child birth. Support to this programme will increase access to sexual and reproductive rights and health services. The programme will also contribute to addressing gender inequality, as well as production of key population data to be used for evidence based programming in Somalia. This will improve women’s well-being, enhance family planning and, as a consequence, increase stability in the region, which is in the Swiss interest.

title: UNDP MPTF Joint Programme on Local Governance
description: After two decades of civil war and the following establishment of an internationally recognised federal government of Somalia in 2012, the UN Joint Programme for Local Governance and Decentralised Service Delivery (JPLG) supports the building up of more effective, accountable and inclusive local governance systems. Focusing on improved regulatory frameworks, enhanced public service delivery, and civic engagement, SDC contributes to enhanced state legitimacy, peacebuilding and more equitable access to public service well-being for all citizens, aiming thereby at more stability in the Horn of Africa.

title: CO Project Management Somalia
description:
The Work in Progress! Alliance is focused on unlocking the economic potential of young women and men in Egypt, Nigeria and Somalia.The project aims to enable them to generate sustainable and reasonable incomes  by finding regular employment or by them starting an enterprise.
The project has a holistic approach because a job alone does not guarantee a successful life in ones own country: 1)It is gender sensitive and inclusive: the programme aims to have 50% of the actively engaged youths be women. Forthe other 50% the programme focuses on the specific needs and participation of young men. 2) It focuses both on the supply and the demand in the labourmarket, and tries to link enterprises and job-seeking youths. 3) And it aims to change policies and develop an enabling environment: advocacy for enabling policies and having role models advocate for youth participation in decision making and at the labour market.
The most important goal of "Work in Progress!" is to improve the skills of young people and their economic prospects by creating jobs and stimulating entrepreneurship. The three major outcomes are as followed: 1) More young men and women have found paid jobs or are running their own enterprises. By improving their employability skills, improvetheir access to information, to exchange platforms to link them to business, accelerators and incubators, and financial investments. 2) Local SMEs see business grow resulting in newly created positions for youth. The project will improve the access to networks, knowledge and credit for Small and Medium Enterprises. 3) Policy measures adopted and implemented that are able to improve labor participation of youth (women in particular), and to promote a business environment. The project will involve influentialpeople in public and private sectors to take a lead in stimulating youth employment and business environment.

title: Work in Progress HAVOYOCO Somalia
description:
The Work in Progress! Alliance is focused on unlocking the economic potential of young women and men in Egypt, Nigeria and Somalia.The project aims to enable them to generate sustainable and reasonable incomes  by finding regular employment or by them starting an enterprise.
The project has a holistic approach because a job alone does not guarantee a successful life in ones own country: 1)It is gender sensitive and inclusive: the programme aims to have 50% of the actively engaged youths be women. Forthe other 50% the programme focuses on the specific needs and participation of young men. 2) It focuses both on the supply and the demand in the labourmarket, and tries to link enterprises and job-seeking youths. 3) And it aims to change policies and develop an enabling environment: advocacy for enabling policies and having role models advocate for youth participation in decision making and at the labour market.
The most important goal of "Work in Progress!" is to improve the skills of young people and their economic prospects by creating jobs and stimulating entrepreneurship. The three major outcomes are as followed: 1) More young men and women have found paid jobs or are running their own enterprises. By improving their employability skills, improvetheir access to information, to exchange platforms to link them to business, accelerators and incubators, and financial investments. 2) Local SMEs see business grow resulting in newly created positions for youth. The project will improve the access to networks, knowledge and credit for Small and Medium Enterprises. 3) Policy measures adopted and implemented that are able to improve labor participation of youth (women in particular), and to promote a business environment. The project will involve influentialpeople in public and private sectors to take a lead in stimulating youth employment and business environment.

title: CO-Drought Response in Somaliland
description:
The latest findings from a countrywide seasonal assessment conducted in December 2016 by the Famine Early Warning Systems Network indicate that over 2.9 million people face Crisis and Emergency (IPC Phases 3 and 4) across Somalia through June 2017. Somalia President Mohamed Abdullahi Farmajo declared the drought a national disaster on 28 February 2017.
Drought affected families are resorting to a range of negative coping strategies including reducing the number of meals eaten in a given day, skipping meals, accumulation of debts or obtaining food on credit from shops, as well as migration in search of livelihood. IDPs rely heavily on support from the host community. Besides, the maternal mortality rate for Somalia is among the highest in the world at 732 maternal deaths per 100,000 live births. Water shortage may also trigger further outbreak of water borne diseases.
Oxfam provides integrated EFSVL (Emergency Food Security and Vulnerable Livelihoods) and WASH (Water, Sanitation and Hygiene) support to vulnerable women, men, boys and girls affected by drought in Sool, Sanaag, Toghdeer and Awdal regions as an immediate life saving intervention whilst taking steps to ensure the response contributes to the capacity building and resilience of communities and partners. Gender and protection will be mainstreamed throughout the response. The key EFSVL interventions include the distribution of cash grants to households who have lost their livestock and financial support to the Ministry of Livestock for scale upof livestock mass vaccination, control of parasites, disease surveillance and treatment of clinical cases. The key WASH interventions include the protection and development of spring and shallow wells, provision of water supply through trucking and vouchers, construction of communal latrines, hygiene promotion activities and distribution of hygiene materials.

title: CO-Danyare Kalkaal (Support the Voiceles
description: Access to justice in Somaliland is a complex issue. Different justice systems work parallel to each other and the awareness of the population which route to justice to take is very low, particularly in rural areas. Government institutions and formal justice providers are primarily based in urban areas in Somaliland. Rural areas have therefore little to no access, making the informal system, Xeer, often the only one to deal with cases. This places women and youth in difficult situations as they do not form part of the elders group. Legal representation in the formal system is dire. Internally Displaced Peoples (IDPs) also face considerable challenges including but not limited to social, economic legal problems, shelter, inaccessibility to land, property, security, health and education. Therefore, with the proposed action this consortium seeks to contribute to increased access to fair and effective justice in Somaliland that adequately deals with community members# grievances, in particular those faced by women, youth, IDPs and minorities

title: CO-Somalia Twinning  Programme
description:
Over the past few years, #localising humanitarian aid# has been regularly raised as a necessity to fundamentally reform the humanitarian system to respond more effectively and equitably to today#s complex crises. The 2016 World Humanitarian Summit (WHS) brought together old and new voices for local humanitarian leadership, creating a space and momentum to speak out and bring change to the system, resulting in The Grand Bargain commitments to advance the localization agenda. In parallel, the Charter4Change, signed on to bymany INGOs, including Oxfam, further commits to reforming the humanitarian system to ensure greater influence and funding for localand national NGOs.

The Somalia NGO Consortium (SNC) and Oxfam Somalia are supporting this movement byplanning and implementing activities to more equitable shift and share power, knowledge, and resources between local, national and international humanitarian actors involved in Somalia#s humanitarian response, with a particular focus on supporting women#srights organisations (WROs) and addressing deeply embedded gender inequities. The SNC#s Strategy 2017-2019 includes as an outcome a #25 per cent of direct funding to Somalia Local NGOs and increased voice and representation with donors, United Nations (UN) and International NGO (INGO) by 2019#. Oxfam Somalia#s humanitarian influencing strategy 2018-2020 aims in its first objective at having more #effective and timely localised aid# to support drought and conflict affected populations. In the strategy, Oxfam Somalia aims to implement the localization agenda in a way that can help address Somalia women#s rights and gender justice and be a powerful agent of women#s transformative leadership in Somalia.

title: SOS Kinderdorpen-Somalia Joint Response
description: The Joint Response for Somalia is a project funded by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs through the Dutch Relief Alliance. Oxfam Novib is leading a consortium that consists of Dorcas, SOS Children#s Villages, World Vision and Oxfam Novib. The proposed projectaims to address the HRP objectives of providing life-saving and life-sustaining integrated, multi-sectoral assistance to reduce acute humanitarian need for communities affected by the drought and protracted conflict. The (revised) Humanitarian Response Plan, dated July 2018, states there are currently 5,4 mln people in need. The locations and sectors for project implementation are to be determined in a planning workshop taking place on 24 and 25 October, with representatives from the participating consortium members and local partners.

title: HO-Somalia Joint Response II
description: The Joint Response for Somalia is a project funded by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs through the Dutch Relief Alliance. In 2020, Oxfam Novib is leading a consortium that consists of Help a Child/ Medair, SOS Children#s Villages, World Vision and Oxfam Novib. The project aims to address the HRP objectives of providing life-saving and life-sustaining integrated, multi-sectoral assistanceto reduce acute humanitarian needs for communities affected by the drought and protracted conflict. The 2020 Joint Response has been designed in line with existing needs relevant to geography, sectors, as well as member#s expertise. Members will continue to implement in the same sectors as the SOMJR 2019: Food Security and Livelihoods, WASH, Health, Nutrition, Protection and Multi-Purpose Cash.

title: Somalia Joint Response II
description: The Somalia Joint Response is a project funded by the Dutch Ministry of Foreign Affairs through the Dutch Relief Alliance. The Consortium consists of four INGOs and six LNGOs and is led by Oxfam Novib. The four INGOs are: Oxfam Novib, Red een Kind, WorldVision and SOS Children#s Villages. The six LNGOs are: TASCO, Havoyoco, Candlelight, ZamZam, Dawa, KAALO. The Somalia Joint Response is present in Somaliland, Puntland and South Central (Mogadishu, Banadir). The proposed project aims to address the HRP objectives of providing life-saving and life-sustaining integrated, multi-sectoral assistance to reduce acute humanitarian need for communities affectedby the drought and protracted conflict. The Somalia Joint Response 2020 is a continuation of the response in 2019, and will focus on the following sectors: FSL, Protection, WASH, Health and Nutrition. A special focus will be on localisation and supporting LNGOs in capacity strengthening and becoming the lead of future responses. Improved accountability to affected populations will underpin the work of the response. The response will also subgrant the Somalia NGO Consortium for activities around localisation, risk management and coordination.

title: Somalia Joint Response 2021
description:
Somalia’s population is currently experiencing multiple shocks (‘triple threat’ – locust, drought, COVID-19): the Desert Locust upsurge that started in late 2019  and continues to threaten the food security and livelihoods of pastoralists and farmers in many parts of the country; riverine and flash floods that affect the food security, livelihoods and safety of farmers and people living in flood-prone, populated areas; the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic that is having severe health and socio-economic impacts both in Somalia and globally; and the extended impact of previous shocks (flooding, drought, displacement, etc.) on livelihoods.
Assessments by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), Food Security and Nutrition Analysis Unit (FSNAU) andFamine Early Warning SystemsNetwork (FEWSNET) also indicate that, in the absence of humanitarian assistance, up to 2.1 million people across Somalia are expected to face food consumption gaps or depletion of assets indicative of Crisis (IPC Phase 3) or worse outcomes through December 2020. In addition, 849 900 children under the age of five are likely to be acutely malnourished through August 2021 . Crisis (IPC Phase 3)outcomes are expected from June to September in parts of central Somalia, where livestock holdings are lowest, and in northeastern Somalia, where the economy is more dependent on livestock, seafood, and frankincense exports. The socioeconomic impacts of COVID-19 have led to a 30-50 % decline in annual external remittances, an anticipated25-35 % decline in annual livestock exports, lower labour demand, and above average imported staple food prices.
Besides adverse weather conditions and conflict resulting in food insecurity and hunger, other prevailing challenges in the project areas Oxfam and partners Candlelight, Havoyoco and KAALO work are poor access to water and inadequate hygiene and sanitation conditions, as well as displacement. Against this backdrop,  the proposed activities aim at assisting both IDPs and host communities. Access to clean and safe water is a major area of concern in our intervention areas in Somaliland and Puntland.
Our proposed activities focus on relieving the distress suffered by affected families, preventing their situation from getting worse and strengthening collective resilience mechanisms. In terms of sectors we will focus on Food Security <(>&<)> Livelihoods (FSL), Water, Sanitation <(>&<)> Hygiene (WASH), Protection (PRO), Multi-Purpose Cash (MPCT) and Accountability (ACC).
Oxfam and partners Candlelight, Havoyoco and KAALO will work in the following regions and districts/locations: Awdal (Baki), Sool (Las Anod, Xudun, Bocaame), Sanaag (Eerigavo), Bari (Bossaso), Mudug (Jariiban). Partners have been implementing SOMJR activities in these regions and locations since 2019 (Awdal, Sool, Sanaag) and 2020 (Bari, Mudug), and were able to invest in the resilience building of target communities. Bocaame in Sool has been added as a new location to the SOMJR: it has already been targeted by partner KAALO during the DRA-funded Desert Locust Joint Response (May to October 2020), however, needs remain high as Bocaame is highly affected by insecurity and recurring waves of desert locust invasions.

title: Somalia Joint Response 2021
description:
Somalia’s population is currently experiencing multiple shocks (‘triple threat’ – locust, drought, COVID-19): the Desert Locust upsurge that started in late 2019  and continues to threaten the food security and livelihoods of pastoralists and farmers in many parts of the country; riverine and flash floods that affect the food security, livelihoods and safety of farmers and people living in flood-prone, populated areas; the novel coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic that is having severe health and socio-economic impacts both in Somalia and globally; and the extended impact of previous shocks (flooding, drought, displacement, etc.) on livelihoods.
Assessments by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO), Food Security and Nutrition Analysis Unit (FSNAU) andFamine Early Warning SystemsNetwork (FEWSNET) also indicate that, in the absence of humanitarian assistance, up to 2.1 million people across Somalia are expected to face food consumption gaps or depletion of assets indicative of Crisis (IPC Phase 3) or worse outcomes through December 2020. In addition, 849 900 children under the age of five are likely to be acutely malnourished through August 2021 . Crisis (IPC Phase 3)outcomes are expected from June to September in parts of central Somalia, where livestock holdings are lowest, and in northeastern Somalia, where the economy is more dependent on livestock, seafood, and frankincense exports. The socioeconomic impacts of COVID-19 have led to a 30-50 % decline in annual external remittances, an anticipated25-35 % decline in annual livestock exports, lower labour demand, and above average imported staple food prices.
Besides adverse weather conditions and conflict resulting in food insecurity and hunger, other prevailing challenges in the project areas Oxfam and partners Candlelight, Havoyoco and KAALO work are poor access to water and inadequate hygiene and sanitation conditions, as well as displacement. Against this backdrop,  the proposed activities aim at assisting both IDPs and host communities. Access to clean and safe water is a major area of concern in our intervention areas in Somaliland and Puntland.
Our proposed activities focus on relieving the distress suffered by affected families, preventing their situation from getting worse and strengthening collective resilience mechanisms. In terms of sectors we will focus on Food Security <(>&<)> Livelihoods (FSL), Water, Sanitation <(>&<)> Hygiene (WASH), Protection (PRO), Multi-Purpose Cash (MPCT) and Accountability (ACC).
Oxfam and partners Candlelight, Havoyoco and KAALO will work in the following regions and districts/locations: Awdal (Baki), Sool (Las Anod, Xudun, Bocaame), Sanaag (Eerigavo), Bari (Bossaso), Mudug (Jariiban). Partners have been implementing SOMJR activities in these regions and locations since 2019 (Awdal, Sool, Sanaag) and 2020 (Bari, Mudug), and were able to invest in the resilience building of target communities. Bocaame in Sool has been added as a new location to the SOMJR: it has already been targeted by partner KAALO during the DRA-funded Desert Locust Joint Response (May to October 2020), however, needs remain high as Bocaame is highly affected by insecurity and recurring waves of desert locust invasions.

title: CO-integrated humanitarian Somalia respo
description:
About 4.6 million people in Somalia are food insecure and 4.2 million are in need of humanitarian assistance. The reduction in the number of people in need since early 2018 has been attributed to favourable rainfall during the Gu season (April to June) and sustained humanitarian assistance. Over 1.5 million people face acute food security Crisis or worse (IPC Phase 3 or higher) and approximately 3.1 million people are Stressed (IPC 2)1. Although the 2016/2017 drought has ended in most parts of Somalia, its adverse impact lingers among those who were impoverished or displaced, and pastoralists who lost all or most of their livestock, particularly in the north. Without sustained food and livelihood assistance, the latter are likely to remain in Emergency (IPC 4).
While acute malnutrition rates have improved nationally to Serious from Critical, the overall prevalence of acute malnutrition remains largely unchanged from Deyr 2017/2018. Between August and December, 294,000 acutely malnourished children, including 55,000 severe cases, aged underfive, will require treatment and integrated support. The acute malnutrition burden over the next 12 months is projected to be 588,400 acutely malnourished children, including 110,500 severe cases. The persistently high levels of acute malnutrition are unlikely toreduce without addressing the underlying causes, particularly in internally displaced persons (IDP) settlements and in some rural areas

title: Oxfam in Somalia Influencing Project
description:
In line with the OCS and Humanitarian Advocacy Strategy, Oxfam#s standalone influencing activities will center on the following thematic areas:
1. Women#s Empowerment: addressing the deep and widespread gender gap, particularly foregrounding the influence of women#s rights organisations.
2. Localisation of Aid: agitating for change related to the persistent barriers towards localisation of aid in both humanitarian and development fields, in close alliance with local and national partners.
3. Debt Relief: in collaboration with the Debt Working Group, seeking expedited, full debt cancellation for Somalia at the highest levels.
4. Youth Empowerment: addressing the specific needs, challenges and aspiration of youth, particularly in terms of influence in decision-making, education and employment.
5. Protection: leveraging our humanitarian presence to identify key protection issues and influence for change, while also feeding into broader protection work, such as with the Regional Durable Solutions Secretariat.

title: CO-Swiss Development Project in Somalila
description:
The project contributes to resilience  building in somaliland, as part of SOMREP effort to addressing the root causes of volubilities.
This project will build  the capacity of people to adopt  climate related Hazards through livelihood diversification, skills development, income generation and community based capacity building,the project will be implemented in Ceel-Afwayn and will be a threeyear period project.
The project is expected to build the resilience  of the community to withstand recurrent  droughts taking place in the area. the nature  of activities  will build on the on going humanitarian responses and act as Nexus between humanitarian and development.

title: CO-50
description: Oxfam in Somalia aims to compare available Google Trends data for Somalia, and Somaliland specifically, with data from existing research and MEAL systems from Oxfam in Somalia and local partners. We will determine if Google Trends data can be used to monitor changes in social norms around women/youth political participation.

title: HO-503001
description: Oxfam in Somalia aims to compare available Google Trends data for Somalia, and Somaliland specifically, with data from existing research and MEAL systems from Oxfam in Somalia and local partners. We will determine if Google Trends data can be used to monitor changes in social norms around women/youth political participation.

title: CO-Contribution To Humanitarian Response
description:
Based on the assessed humanitarian needs and projections for 2019, the response strategy remains focused on a two-pronged approach:

1.) To provide urgent life-saving, life-sustaining and dignity upholding assistance in response to food insecurity, water shortage, disease outbreak and protection risks that are faced as a result of recurrent drought.
2.) Investing in resilience and recovery interventions to work with communities, government institutions and other key stakeholders towards a more sustainable solution to the cyclical disasters in Somalia.

Overall Goal: To meet the immediate life-saving needs of 500,000 drought affected people and providesustainable solutions to improve the coping capacity of vulnerable communities to the effects of drought.

It must be stressed thatcross-cutting the entire humanitarian strategy is a commitment to localisation, safe programming working closely alongside local partners, line ministries and communities in implementing the response and recovery interventions, building capacity and longer-term sustainability along the way.

title: Support of NEXUS Consortium in Somalia
description:
Nexus is launching an Institutional Development Unit to invest strategically in the growth of its members, research critical areas to develop action-oriented agendas for thought leadership and advocacy, and advance partnerships with Somali government entities andthe private sector. This project will kickstart these initial Nexus interventions in three areas that together will provide a critical foundation for Nexus# thought leadership and civil society strengthening efforts in years to come, particularly in relation to gender justice:
1. Delivery of a 6-month gender leadership program to support gender champions inside and outside its platform, both civil society and government.
2. Research into women#s leadership in humanitarian
response in Somalia and Somaliland to be leveragedfor advancing women#s leadership.
3. Establishment of the Institutional Development Unit, including development of common criteria and institutional development plans.

title: Shuraako  SMEs Competition
description:
We will select 3 companies to enter into a dedicated scale-up trajectory; 1 company per country. The pilot will be running in Somalia, Egypt, and Uganda. The goal of the trajectory is to professionalize their (international) growth strategy and where possible to help find (international) partners, in supply, trade or investment.

Objectives
The primary objective of the competition is to accelerate societal (innovative) impact through SMEs and start-ups <(>&<)> job opportunities for youth. The secondary objective of this pilot is to get the best examples of impact-driven SMEs in our countries and understand what it takes for them to scale-up, both their business and impact. This will allow us to improve our programme further by including working with superstar impact SMEs into our approach. Thirdly, we can use these #superstars# as best examples of the kind of companies we want to support, so to use it in our communication towards donors, investors, other Oxfam countries and other stakeholders.

title: CO-Somaliland -Work in Progress!! II
description:
Our strategy combines service delivery, such as trainings, with influencing interventions to change policies, laws, attitudes and beliefs. This has proved successful in the last three years. The strategy engages young women and men from diverse backgrounds to be a driving force for social progress and optimism about the future in their respective countries and across Africa.

When we worked with stakeholders in each country to analyse the current situation faced by young men and women, we found three common key needs:
1. Improving curricula and training methods, creating new modules and connecting the curricula to the demands of the market.
2. Innovation to respond to social issues such as climate change, gender rights and urbanization.
3. Linking service delivery interventions with influencing interventions # young people do not need only better training and new skills, but also changes to the system: policies, laws, practices and the attitudes and beliefs of their fellow citizens, employers and the government.
These conclusions have guided this proposal in further developing interventions and adapting activities for each country for 2020-2022. We will highlight new interventions in the following chapters.

Our strategy is based on systems thinking: trying to understand how different parts of a system interact to effect change, rather than understanding specific components in isolation. Systems thinking can help to develop truly sustainable and transformative change. The below graphic illustrates the #system# for youth seeking employment in Somaliland, mapping the relationships of actors including education institutions, hubs, teachers, government, banks, entrepreneurs, families and media.

title: CO-Somalia Drought Response (Marisla)
description:
Somalia has experienced recurrent droughts since 2011 which have been increasingly exacerbated by climate change. Agro-pastoralistsand pastoralists have been badly affected by the 2019 drought which has caused widespread crop failure, water shortages, and depleted livestock levels.
More than 4.2 million people were estimated to be in need of humanitarian assistance in 2019, and the number ofpeople who are food insecure is expected to increase in the coming months.  This year#s severe drought has been caused by abnormally hot, dry conditions during January-March and the failure of the rains in April-June. Most households are already adopting negativecoping strategies to mitigate food insecurity, including reducing food intake. Poor transportation and market infrastructure make it difficult for pastoralists to access markets, and there are few fed markets to provide animals with nutrition when natural pastures are inadequate. Over 80% of livestock was lost as a result of the 2017 drought, and the population of livestock herds, essential for pastoralists# food and income, have not yet recovered.
The impact of the 2019 drought on the water and sanitation sector has beensignificant. Water supply (boreholes, shallow wells) is severely limited and the cost of accessing water has increased sharply, representing a severe burden on insufficient household income. Existing groundwater sources contain a highly mineralized content, rendering it unsuitable for drinking, but a prior Oxfam needs assessment showed that the vast majority of households in the project area do not treat their water. Open defecation remains common, increasing protection risks for women and girls who venture outside alone or during the night or move far from dwellings to known open defecation areas.
Oxfam aims to assist at least 500,000 affected peoplewith immediate food security and WASH programming along with resilience and recovery interventions to diminish the impact of recurring droughts on vulnerable populations. Oxfam will embed activities to strengthen the protection of women, men, boys, and girls within the EFSVL and WASH workstreams.

title: CO-DRA POC Development Process Somalia
description:
Core Humanitarian Standard, evidence-based and that meets needs holistically by integrating a triple nexus approach. This model will be peer-reviewed by other experts in the Global South. Once further funding is secured, it will become operational, with multiple organizations making varied, layered contributions to common outcomes according to their strengths # to ensure humanitarian responses uphold interwoven development and peace objectives and are thereby sustainable and transformative.
Additionally, the platform willproduce a robust operating procedure for its Anticipatory Response Fund, which serves as an emergency response mechanism/crisis modifier. Many INGOs, including Oxfam in Myanmar and Bangladesh, have successfully piloted this response mechanism with local partners.Upon request by local partners, the Somalia Joint Response is also piloting this mechanism with local partners in 2020, and all SOMJR INGOs have included a crisis modifier in their budgets in 2020. The Anticipatory Response Fund serves as a means for local humanitarian partners to quickly access funding to respond to sudden crises and emergencies. The fund's aim is to address funding gaps andensure quick access to emergency funding for local responders. The fund will build oncurrent initiatives in country to promote local humanitarian leadership and preparedness, and deliver on commitments made in the Grand Bargain and Charter for Change by donor andNGO signatories. It will also identify strengths and areas for capacity development in relation to emergency response in Somalia The operating procedure for the Anticipatory Response Fund will include triggers and related protocols, such that a pilot test of triggers, collaboration mechanisms and protocols can take place ahead ofthe humanitarian response windows, in the second half of 2020.
Beyond the pilot phase, these actions will lay the foundations for a response mechanism that is pre-emptive and therefore efficient and highly responsive # improving the quality of locally-led humanitarian response in Somalia and Somaliland. Delivering on the ambition statement (i.e. development of above-mentioned model for humanitarian programming and operating procedures) will contribute to all four DRA strategic priorities: 1) more effective support for locally-led responses by supporting Nexus as locally-led platform; 2) innovation and learning by generating knowledge outputs and new ways of working; 3) collaboration for increased effectiveness by bringing together a wide range of localactors with coverage of all 9 regions of Somalia and Somaliland; and 4) more accountable humanitarian action by giving voice and decision making power to local organisations and adding rigor through South-South peer review.

title: Citizenship Project
description:
The Ministry of Parliamentary Relations and Constitutional Affairs #MoPCA# has been conducting awareness programs aimed at educating citizens about their constitutional rights and their obligations. Thus far, MoPCA has implemented an awareness programs, which arenow broadcast on Radio and TV. The radio program has a wide coverage of people as it reaches almost all over the country. Furthermore, MoPCA has signed agreement with the Ministry of Education and Science as regards incorporating civic educationcourses into the curriculum of high primary schools, secondary schools and universities. The curriculum for the three preceding streams has been finalized recently and the teaching of the civic education is expected to begin soon.
In addition, MoPCA intends to train all government institutions to ensure that such institutions respect the constitutional rights of the citizens. The essence of the training of the government institutions on the constitutional rights is to enhance the protection of basic human rights and to strengthen the rule of law. So far, MoPCA has trained the Good Governance and Anti Corruption Commission as well as 1000 young men who were undertaking their National Service training at Dararweyne training school. The ministry also visited regional universities to train National Service girls who were attached to different universities to complete their national service requirements. MoPCA will continue training other government institutions on constitutional rights of the citizens.
Similarly, the Ministry has also distributed large quantities of the copies of the constitution as well as brochures and pamphlets aimed at raising citizens# awareness vis-à-vis their constitutional rights and their obligations as well. The ministry is also planning to visit regions and hold town-hall meetings with different citizens residing in regions. The aim of these town-hall meetings is to disseminate the constitution and to gather data as regards the views and opinions of society with respect to theirknowledge about their constitutional rights. MoPCA will also undertake consultative meetings in all regions.

title: CO-Enhancing Resilience in Somaliland II
description:
Specific objective/ Outcome:  Sustainably improve food security and livelihoods of Somali people, households, communities through effective risk management, protection of productive assets, improved governance of resilience structures, and promotion of innovations and evidence based programming.
Intermediary Outcome 1: Improved capacity of households to implement disaster risk management and positive coping strategies to mitigate the immediate effect of exposure to shock.
Intermediary Outcome 2: Improved capacity of individuals, households and communities to adhere to positive development trajectories; despite exposures to shocks and utilize strategies designed to allow adaptation to rapid and slow on-set hazards.
Intermediary Outcome 3: Improved capacity to engage in strategies for sustainable livelihoods and economic growth to enhance food security and resilience

title: CO-Somalia Desert Locust Response Projec
description:
Specific objective:  To curb the spread of Desert Locust, pprotect and recover Livelihoods of the people affected by Locust disaster in Somaliland and Puntland.
Result 1: Improved locust control mechanisms and capacitate/enable government and local community to minimize negative effects on livelihoods of people affected by desert locust.
Result 2: Reduced impact of desert locust and support early livelihood recovery through provision critical agriculture inputs and livestock fodder.
Activities
1.1. Support 10 community mobilization campaigns and trainings at ground level, on locust control.
1.2. 600 people undertake mechanical control (digging trenches and driving hopper bands into them) through cash for work
1.3. 3 community awareness campaigns through media outlets, reaching 24 villages with an average population of 350 HHs each (8500HHs to be reached through awareness and outreach on locust).
1.4        Conduct one baseline, and one Post Distribution Monitoring.

description:

title: Increasing  Agricultural Production
description:
Oxfam has rehabilitated dozens of boreholes in Sool and Sanaag region, most of those water structure has solar system in place. Oxfam#s assessment found pout that some of those structures are not used by people due to varying reasons. Oxfam EFSVL and WASH team discussed this issue and propose we combine water and agricultural production. Oxfam will support ministry of agriculture to assess 6-7 water points in those two regions aimed to start agricultural production. The government will mobilize communities and familiarizethem agricultural production. It is expected that linking existing water sites to agriculture will improve nutritional. Mionistry of agriculture will enhane agricultural practices by introducing agriculture around those water points. The ministry will provide seeds, knowledge regularly using its field staff.
Nutrition-Sensitive Agriculture is good-based approach to agricultural development that puts nutritionally rich foods, dietary diversity and food fortification at the heart of overcoming malnutrition and micronutrientdeficiencies. This assignment focuses on the utilization of water resource for agriculture sector to improve the nutritional value of foods for good nutrition, health and productivity, and social significance of farming and supporting rural livelihood specially that pregnant, lactating women and child.
# The main objective of this mission is to investigate the suitability of borehole water resource for utilization for irrigation purpose.
# Understanding Perception of the community for benefiting water for agriculture purpose
# The MOAD consultants will observe the appropriateness of nature of land (soil type, topography, soil nutrient) for crop production and predict the method of irrigation that could be used.
# During the field exercise, the consultants will analyze the proper ways of community water allocation for domestic use, animal watering and irrigation.
# The consultants will investigate the current situation of agricultural production status and level of nutrition of beneficiaries# community.
# Consultants will have soil and water samples

title: CO-Desert Locust Crisis Response
description:
Specific objective:  To curb the spread of Desert Locust, pprotect and recover Livelihoods of the people affected by Locust disaster in Somaliland and Puntland.
Result 1: Improved locust control mechanisms and capacitate/enable government and local community to minimize negative effects on livelihoods of people affected by desert locust.
Result 2: Reduced impact of desert locust and support early livelihood recovery through provision critical agriculture inputs and livestock fodder

title: CO-Somalia Locust Control Measures
description:
Oxfam has been working in Somalia for over 40 years, working with Somali people and organisations implementing humanitarian, resilience and development programmes. Humanitarian response focuses on WaSH, EVFSL and Protection.
Oxfam has made a lot of gains through humanitarian resilience programmes which are likely to be eroded if the desert locust menace is uncontrolled. Oxfam will therefore capitalise and work with the existing community structures such as Early Warning Committees, Government line ministries, FAO and other stakeholders on the preventive and control measures.
Oxfam will prioritize safeguarding livelihoods focusing on cash intervention and locust control measures.

A total of 1,056 people in coastal areas of Sool region will be reachedby the project and supported toprotect and recover their livelihoods.

Oxfam has vast experience in implementing conditional and unconditional cash transfer approaches in WASH, EVFSL programmes. The project will specifically focus on the Cash for Work(CfW) approach as it not only empowers individuals to spend based on their priority needs but also focuses on revamping community assets. CfW will therefore stimulate the recovery of the local economy by creating short-term work, reintroduce income flow,supporting local businesses through the purchase worktools while also encouraging households to purchase food and non-food items locally. The trench digging will involve large numbers of the population and will be designed to encourage the integration and participation of women and other marginalized groups in an area thus benefitting the entire community and not just a few individuals.

The project will support communities to address locust spread by burying them in trenches excavated through cash for work. A total of 1,056 people will dig 26 km of trenches and drive hopper bands through cash for work, this task will continue for 30 days, 15 days per month starting in mid-March 2020. This task is expected to minimize hopper bands probability to turn to dangerous swarm level while at the same time communities will be able to access cash to help them address food insecurity situation at household level.

Oxfam will closely cooperate with the Somaliland Ministry of agriculture

title: CO-COVID-19 Help Line
description:
a. Receive and make calls to the application through existing three-digit toll free short code.
b. Manages region-based calls and direct to appropriate call centers in the six Somaliland regions.
c. Customize existing application to handle multiple calls at the same time.
d. Provide an option for callers to access up to date information on the virus based on the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines through toll free number (Telesom will cover Short code and calling minutes).
e. Provide Symptoms screening checker to all callers to answer few questions over the phone to determine whether they at risk and provide appropriate advice.
f.  Speak to caller center operator for further information and support.
2. Assisting capacitate the existing call center in Hargeisa and establish additional 5 call centers with three health workers manning each call center.
3. Train the call center staff to manage the help line platform, receive calls, process audio messages and call back people who could not get through. Provide regular reports to committee and potential high risks cases for action when the times comes.
4. Maintain and support the platform for the duration of the pandemic.
5. The ministry would also create group of their health works system to send out rapid messages.

The key feature of the service isthe ability to handle multiple calls, leave voice messages if the caller can#t get through, symptoms screening and provision of up to date information as per the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines.
A total of 18 call center staff volunteers from the Ministry of Health will be trained through a two days workshop in Hargeisa to train them on the platform and dealing with callers during this difficult time. Three call center volunteers will be selected from each of the six main regions in Somaliland including Marodijeex, Awdal, Saxil, Todgheer, Sool and Sanaag. Volunteers will through shifts and lines will be closed from 5pm each day and opens at 7am.During this time, system will direct all callers to voice mail system. It is expected that there will be large number of spam messages and the platform will be designed to handle spam callers.

title: COVID-19 Help Line
description:
a. Receive and make calls to the application through existing three-digit toll free short code.
b. Manages region-based calls and direct to appropriate call centers in the six Somaliland regions.
c. Customize existing application to handle multiple calls at the same time.
d. Provide an option for callers to access up to date information on the virus based on the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines through toll free number (Telesom will cover Short code and calling minutes).
e. Provide Symptoms screening checker to all callers to answer few questions over the phone to determine whether they at risk and provide appropriate advice.
f.  Speak to caller center operator for further information and support.
2. Assisting capacitate the existing call center in Hargeisa and establish additional 5 call centers with three health workers manning each call center.
3. Train the call center staff to manage the help line platform, receive calls, process audio messages and call back people who could not get through. Provide regular reports to committee and potential high risks cases for action when the times comes.
4. Maintain and support the platform for the duration of the pandemic.
5. The ministry would also create group of their health works system to send out rapid messages.

The key feature of the service isthe ability to handle multiple calls, leave voice messages if the caller can#t get through, symptoms screening and provision of up to date information as per the Ministry of Health and WHO guidelines.
