title: CO-COVID-19 Pandemic II
description:
# Solarization of two existing water sources   in Baki and Saylac districts of Awdal benefiting more than 10,000 people and their livestock. Awdal is one of the regions affected by COVID19 as it connects Somaliland to Djibouti. The majority of people are dependent pity trades, small scale irrigation, and livestock, most of these activities have been affected, and communities reported a reduction of income. Existing water supply sources are mainly powered by a diesel generator that are purchased from the tariffs collected from the users. Associated water tariffs are sky rocking as access to diesel has reduced as restrictions are imposed on public transport. Out of the many strategic water sources, two sources are selected, supplying water for villages affected by COVID19 in Somaliland. Oxfam will install a solar system for these wells, and the action will reduce the cost of water tariff and increase community use of water for different purposes include handwashing.
# Build the capacity of the WASH committees managing the solarizedse water sources by providing necessary tools and training them on both technical skill and financial management. This action will be led by the ministry of water department of scheme management. As we mobilize for the two sources an additional two boreholes within the sameareas will also be invited for the training. These will help to maximize use of expert time, cover nearby villages with capacity building plan and increase value for money by targeting more with same budget.
# Support Somaliland Ministry of Water Development to ministry of water to finalize   the design and construction for WASH facilities to be shared with all WASH Cluster members in Somaliland. The national WASH cluster has prioritized this action as per the request from ministry and Oxfam will contribute for this action. The budget will be used to cover some of the consultancy fees or provide expertise to help them finalize the work.
# Provide safeprogramming training for WaSH committees, district administrations, women groups other key stakeholders including traditional leaders    .
# Protection awareness raising including community discussions on protection impact to address stigma and promotion of the call centre hotline   (already operational) to increase access to covid19 services for affected communities    .
# Government capacity building/strengthen social safety net system in Somaliland : we will build the capacity of the government to be able to lead and coordinate Somaliland safety net program. Somalia launched safety net project called bahnano at Mogadishu but this has not been cascaded to Somaliland and Puntland. The government staff responsible for this are unable to run safety net due to their limited capacity. The project will target technical staff from the government and create enabling environment in the form of institutional capacity building including training of key staff, support implementation of beneficiaries selection and running coordination mechanisms smoothly.  Oxfam Somalia is implementing social safety net activity under GFFO top up. Under this activity the project aims improving supports to HHs in urban areas particularly COVID19 affected poorest or most vulnerable to prevent them to fall to poverty and destitution trap, manage COVID19 economic and social shocks and advance their lives <(>&<)> livelihoods. The government capacity in Somaliland on social safety net is to grow and as part of appeal fund, Oxfam will contribute to strengthening/establishing social protection system that leads COVID19 response project. Oxfam will partner with Somaliland Ministry of Employment, Social and Family as socialprotection responsible government body. Somaliland government capacity is yet to grow and this project will address this gap while also coordinating with other implementing agencies to strengthen their capacity to be able to lead social assistance and provide at scale in the future to its society as a right. The project creates an opportunity for governments to become the standard responders to large scale crises.

title: SOCIAL INNOVATION PROJECTS
description:
Harhub in partnership with Oxfam is launching a social innovation challenge to tackle most pressing social issues. The partners areaiming to harness the innovations of young people in Somaliland and beyond particularly social entrepreneurs, developers, changemakers, and health practitioners keen on bringing game-changing solutions to most vital social challenges focusing on in the areas of agriculture, technology, SDGs, health, food, education, and energy. The partners believe that tackling these complex issues will require diverse skill sets, backgrounds, effort and innovation. Harhub will be prioritizing innovations which may already be proven but will reach new heights of interest within the industry given the right support from Harhub, or innovations which are new ideas and concepts, but might need some tuning to fit the requirements of potential customers.
Through a competitive process, Harhub will reachout to 10k youth through social media promotions to apply the program for three weeks. Harhub is expected to receive quite big and competitive projects. Whilst applicants are ongoing, Harhub will create mentors’ criteria and hire 3 mentors to lead selection and the Bootcamp. All the submitted projects will be evaluated by the mentors based on the solutions’ unique value proposition, social impact, visibility, technical viability, and the individuals’/teams’ ability and capability to scale the solution.

In total, the mentors will then select twenty most advanced and innovative projects to attendthe two full days Bootcamp to be held at Harhub. The Bootcamp will be a high-energy workshop focused on rapid ideation, refinement, and prototyping of solutions. It is a space to generate, iterate on, and test ideas for social impact, foster a culture ofinnovation through experimentation, collaboration, and expand a community of social impact innovators. In the final event, twenty finalists will pitch their solutions for a chance to win grant funding, incubation, and mentorship scheme. The top three projects will be awarded a grant fund to their projects at Harhub with all support of providing free incubation and mentorship to develop, validate, execute and scale their solutions

title: Women In Tech
description:
Somaliland has a population of over 3.7 million. According to Somaliland’s Ministry of Labour and Social Affairs, UNDP and the World Bank reports, over 70% of Somaliland’s population is under the age of 30. The unemployment rate for youth aged 15 to 30 is 67% - one of the highest rates in the world. Among young women, it is even estimated at 74%. Youth in Somaliland are not just the future ofthe country, they are also the majority.
With 67% of the youth being out of work, the high unemployment rate forthe youth remains abig challenge in Somaliland, and this rate is even higher for young women. The unemployment rate for young women in the country is estimated to be 74%. Due to the insecurity over the last two decade and stagnant economic growth, jobs have not been created at a rate that is able to match the growth of the youth population.
Women often face stiff competition during business pitching/competitions and often shy away to compete with their fellow men or observe stigmatization. This conceptwill bridge this gap by specifically earmarking this Women in Tech competition for young women tech savvies to compete among each other.
To achieve a long lasting and sustainable economic and social transformation in the country, we must empower young women, create opportunities for prosperity and provide them with the necessary tools and resources.
Hence Innovate Ventures (IV) in partnership and collaboration with Oxfam aim to support, accelerate and grow the Somali women startup scene and accelerate the growth of women startups in technology to help them create employment opportunities, and improve the investment climate in the country

title: Digital Influence In Decision Making
description:
This project will address the digital information and campaigning gaps that will push women’s rights and political participation inthe public agendas of Somalia/Somaliland. This will be achieved through development of powerful and change-inspiring campaigns to be promulgated through various digital platforms – Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and TV channels. Extensive discussions are occurring online in Somalia/Somaliland, which have significance on the national debate, with middle class and urban youth being particularly active online. Their subsequent influence on community-level discussions is significant and thus need to be shaped by appropriate information. Featuring video and other engaging content, will help counter negative online discussions and contribute towards greater public acceptance of women’s rights in Somaliland.
This project will engage a range of actors working on women’s rights and digital influencing. NAGAAD Network and SSWC, two leading women’s rights organizations and an established partners of Oxfam, will lead in coordinating campaigns by engaging relevant actors that will add weight to the campaigns. NAGAAD and SSWC will organize workshops and debate sessions where burning issues around women’s political participation and how best to influence increased representation of women in elected bodies.
This project will empower women and female youth activists to use social media to shape public perceptions of gender ideas, beliefs, and values and serve as an important means of generating women’s awareness about their subordinate or even oppressed status. A group of prominent social media campaigners will be established to create campaigns and hashtags and frequently post, retweet news, commentaries, and articles to enhance the visibility of various women’s issues at global and national levels. These campaigns will shed light on specific issues including fighting domestic violence, women’s rights, sexual harassment in the workplace, gender equality, women’s development, and stereotypedgender representations in the media.

title: CO-Locust Response II
description: The aim to undertake pastoral field school demonstration site linked to mechanical locust control community level. Oxfam will establish one demo site in El-afweyn. Pastoral field schools participants will participate interactive on site learning events for a period of 5-10 days. Essential assorted tools and to be procured in advance by Oxfam. Oxfam staff will conduct the training in collaboration with ministry of agriculture. A total of 60 people will benefit this project who are invited from near by locations who are locust prone sites and equipped with mechanical control skills. Preparation of raised beds include also the inputs essential for this task

title: CO-Local Humanitarian Leadership (Nexus)
description:
6.3 million people are currently in need of humanitarian assistance across Somalia and Somaliland, with 2.6 million internally displaced and an estimated 1 million displaced in nearby countries. Whilst the deepening climate crisis exacerbates needs, Somalia and Somaliland are becoming increasingly stable, as persistent war gives way to erratic conflict and increasing capacity of government. Despite this, international actors face the obstacles of persistent issues of restricted access and highly challenging security circumstances. Local actors by contrast are able to transcend these issues and to guide interventions with nuanced local knowledge. This represents an opportunity to lead and deliver humanitarian aid locally. Somalia is one of the countries where a Joint Response to a protracted crisis under the DRA (SOMJR) is being implemented. With the changing context towards greater local leadership, the SOMJR already focuses on widening the space for local responders in humanitarian emergencies and decision-making fora. However, the Joint Response is fully led by INGOs, which inevitably creates unequal power dynamics that can negatively impact on the meaningful localization sought by local partners in Somalia. The protracted crisis situation, the long-standing presence of the DRA in Somalia, as well as the emergence of strong local humanitarian actors present the reality in which this PoC process can be carried out, and where an innovative pilot Joint Response focusing on meaningful localization would beworth exploring.
The Nexus Platform is an innovative response to the need for joined-up, localized responses at the triple nexus of humanitarian, development and peace programming: intervening to deliver coordinated outputs in all 3 spheres, which is essential in the Somali context, where climate shocks and conflict perpetually undermine humanitarian and development outcomes and deepen humanitarian crises. Although specifically tackled in the Somali context here – climate shocks and conflict are global causes of ongoing humanitarian crises, making the Nexus Platform’s approach pertinent to challenges at the triple nexus in parallel circumstances. Comprised of nine local NGOs (footprint 30m USD), Oxfam andSave the Children International and entirely locally led, the platform is operational across every region of Somalia and Somaliland. The platform is built upon principles of South-to-South learning and civil society strengthening, whereby expertise is openly exchanged between member organizations to build a consortium that is more than the sum of its parts. Humanitarian response is central tothe platform’s nascent phase. The platform envisions both multisectoral humanitarian response and the development of an Anticipatory Response Mechanism – utilisingthe platform’s breadth of local access to trigger pre-emptive early action. The platform urgently needs – and is invested in developing – a model for its humanitarian programme areas through a PoC process which will allow the platform to rethink conventional humanitarian approaches that are particularly open to question in contexts such as Somalia. The process used to develop this model will be additionally adapted for the development of the platform’s ways of working in the development and peace spheres:whilst humanitarian actions are the platform’s immediate priority in its current scope of work, programs exemplifying locally-led decision making are planned in community development, government and civil society strengthening, women’s empowerment and other areas across the triple nexus and these will require their own guiding PoC processes.

title: Local Humanitarian Leadership (Nexus)
description:
6.3 million people are currently in need of humanitarian assistance across Somalia and Somaliland, with 2.6 million internally displaced and an estimated 1 million displaced in nearby countries. Whilst the deepening climate crisis exacerbates needs, Somalia and Somaliland are becoming increasingly stable, as persistent war gives way to erratic conflict and increasing capacity of government. Despite this, international actors face the obstacles of persistent issues of restricted access and highly challenging security circumstances. Local actors by contrast are able to transcend these issues and to guide interventions with nuanced local knowledge. This represents an opportunity to lead and deliver humanitarian aid locally. Somalia is one of the countries where a Joint Response to a protracted crisis under the DRA (SOMJR) is being implemented. With the changing context towards greater local leadership, the SOMJR already focuses on widening the space for local responders in humanitarian emergencies and decision-making fora. However, the Joint Response is fully led by INGOs, which inevitably creates unequal power dynamics that can negatively impact on the meaningful localization sought by local partners in Somalia. The protracted crisis situation, the long-standing presence of the DRA in Somalia, as well as the emergence of strong local humanitarian actors present the reality in which this PoC process can be carried out, and where an innovative pilot Joint Response focusing on meaningful localization would beworth exploring.
The Nexus Platform is an innovative response to the need for joined-up, localized responses at the triple nexus of humanitarian, development and peace programming: intervening to deliver coordinated outputs in all 3 spheres, which is essential in the Somali context, where climate shocks and conflict perpetually undermine humanitarian and development outcomes and deepen humanitarian crises. Although specifically tackled in the Somali context here – climate shocks and conflict are global causes of ongoing humanitarian crises, making the Nexus Platform’s approach pertinent to challenges at the triple nexus in parallel circumstances. Comprised of nine local NGOs (footprint 30m USD), Oxfam andSave the Children International and entirely locally led, the platform is operational across every region of Somalia and Somaliland. The platform is built upon principles of South-to-South learning and civil society strengthening, whereby expertise is openly exchanged between member organizations to build a consortium that is more than the sum of its parts. Humanitarian response is central tothe platform’s nascent phase. The platform envisions both multisectoral humanitarian response and the development of an Anticipatory Response Mechanism – utilisingthe platform’s breadth of local access to trigger pre-emptive early action. The platform urgently needs – and is invested in developing – a model for its humanitarian programme areas through a PoC process which will allow the platform to rethink conventional humanitarian approaches that are particularly open to question in contexts such as Somalia. The process used to develop this model will be additionally adapted for the development of the platform’s ways of working in the development and peace spheres:whilst humanitarian actions are the platform’s immediate priority in its current scope of work, programs exemplifying locally-led decision making are planned in community development, government and civil society strengthening, women’s empowerment and other areas across the triple nexus and these will require their own guiding PoC processes.

title: CO-Response To  Cyclone Crisis in Somali
description:
The program will be achieved through focusing on unconditional cash transfer transfers targeting the most vulnerable IDPs and host communities affected by COVID 19 economically and exacerbated by GATI cyclone, based on the food consumption scoring and loss of livelihood assets. This intervention forms approximately 70% of the total cash transfer programming under Oxfam’s overall response and will be implemented directly by Oxfam by engaging electronic financial service provider in Puntland via mobile phones. Beneficiarieswho don’t possess Sim-cards will receive them as part of this response and be trained on its usage. The overall Oxfam food securityintervention which this contributes towards will include additional emergency livelihoods and recovery elements including cash for work interventions to rebuild destroyed feeder roads.Oxfam targets households that meet the critical food insecurity criteria takingintoconsideration gender-differentiated needs. The selection criteria will be discussed with thetarget women, men, boys and girls toensure fairness of the selection process. Usually, women are registered as beneficiaries and the head of the household for cash transfers. At times we find that some polygamous households are includedduring registration stage and this is addressed during verification, ensuring that the most vulnerable HH are Commented [AC12]: In addition to these activities DEC funds can also be used to coverany hygiene promotion activities/hygiene kits, COVID messaging, PPE for staffif needed?Commented [MH13R12]: We Have some PPE in thefield, Moses to add purchase of some PPE in the budget
targeted, in collaboration with community leaders. Female-headed households are the most affected as they do not have access to meaningful household assets such as livestock, or other sources of income. In Bari region, priorities for livelihood regeneration activities are different for women and men. Oxfam will deliver emergency food security interventions through cash grants for the most vulnerable people, while supporting household income by strengtheningand diversifying livelihoods through other projects. Oxfam's programming since March 2017 has successfully diversified the source of livelihoods in traditional pastoralist communities in Somaliland with plansto replicate this expereicnce in Puntland. This intervention will help vulnerable households to have some disposable income which they can use to purchase or meet their household food needs.Most vulnerable community members that will be most in need of the emergency assistance through this action will be identified through participatory mapping exercises conducted at village level through specific exercises including well-being rankings, vulnerability mapping, food consumption score, household purchasing power, among others. Gender will be consideredwhen selecting households to help reduce the additional burden on women headedhouseholds. The criteria shall be clearly explained to the selection committee/panel prior toselection, with clearcommunication on what beneficiaries will be entitled to during the project, to avoid unrealistic expectations.

title: CO-EFSL & WASH Based COVID-19 Response
description: Somalia is one  of the  most  fragile and complex humanitarian crises in  the world. The country is emerging from more than three decades of conflicts with weak formal government systems since the collapse of the central  governmentin  the  early  1990s.Decades  ofarmed  conflicts  coupled  with  recurrent  drought conditions,  famine,  persistent  food  insecurity,  protracted  population  displacement  as  well  as  seasonal flooding  have left the country suffering one of the world’s worst humanitarian  situations.  The southern Somalia  has  been  the  worst  affected  with  the  region  experiencing  cycles  of  conflict  that  have  destroyed legitimate  institutions  and  created  widespread  vulnerability.  While  situation  was  dire  alreadydueto protracted  conflicts and drought, COVID 19 pandemic emergence detoriorated both health and livelihood sources of Somali community. In DEC phase 2, Oxfam plans to provide an integrated WASH and food security project to support emergency food  crises and  support  recovery  of livelihoods lost  due  to  drought  or  COVID  19  pandemic  in  Puntland, Jubaland and Somaliland administrative regions of Somalia. EFSVL Component: The project will addresshumanitarian needs of the IDPs, poor urban and returnees and will support cash and voucher assistance(CVA) to people affected by triple threats of conflict, drought and COVID 19 economically. This will be complemented to supportingLivelihood restoration for women groups affected  by  COVID  pandemic toenable  them to resume  or  establish  viable  livelihood options  intended  to provide  sustainable  livelihood  opportunities  for  affected  IDPs,  returnees  and  host  community  in  target 11regions of Somalia. This outcome will alleviate the sufferingof 6,780 people from extreme effects of COVID 19 i mpact and improve their food security situation. WASH Outcomes: A total of 8000people are expected to benefit from rehabilitation of three strategic water points  coupled  by  hygiene  and  promotion activities.  COVID  19  awareness  raising  will  be  conducted  for 60,000people  in  all  target  regions  of  the  project  with  the  aim  of  reducing  spread  of  this  pandemic. This outcome will benefita total of 60,000people. The project will benefita total of 60,000peopleand will be implemented in the same districts as DEC phase 1 in Puntland and Somaliland while the project target Kismayo district of Lower Juba region. Oxfam continues to work with WASDA in this project and implementationmodalitywill remain mixed approach.  The activities are in line with Oxfam’s Humanitarian Strategy forSomalia and contributes to our Oxfam Coutnry Strategy (OSC)2020-2025.

title: CO-Drought & Sever Water Shortages Respo
description:
2020 was one of the hardest years for Somalia in decades. Flooding, COVID-19 and recurring locust invasions heavily impacted on theeconomy and livelihoods of people. The government implemented measures to contain COVID-19, including the closure of schools, reduction of movement and other economic activities. The coastal areas of Puntland and Somaliland were also hit by cyclone Gati in November 2020, resulting in a sharp increase in humanitarian needs which many organizations - including Oxfam Somalia - responded to. While the performance of the 2020 Gu rain was near normal, the Deyr rain of 2020 has been categorized a complete failure due to the La Nina conditions. These developments triggered severe water shortages in many regions and districts in Somalia. Since October 2020, regional administrations, communities and other humanitarian agencies have been sending alerts about looming drought conditions in many parts of Somalia.Oxfam’s feedback hotline continues to receive a high number of calls from people requesting immediate water interventions. These callers are mainly from the Sool, Sanaag and Togdheer regions. UNOCHA assessment findings indicate that over 50% of the communities in the assessed locations reported displacement of people due to water shortages, 85% raised major concerns on watershortages, and 14 out of 40 villages reported an increase in diarrheal cases. The price of water has already more than doubled. According to Oxfam’s own market assessment, one barrel of water is currently being sold at an average of USD 4.5 per barrel, with some villages reporting over USD 7 per barrel. This is forcing the most vulnerable households to travel long distances to fetch water and/or opt for poor water quality and risk their lives. The most affected communities include IDPs and low-income host communities. Women and girls are at risk of protection-related risks as they travel in search of water.
Regarding COVID-19, over 4,784 cases with over 130 fatalities were registered by the WHO in Somalia since the start of the pandemic, with many cases left undetected due to asymptomatic infections, low testing capacity and the stigmatisation of COVID-19 cases among the population. The second wave of the pandemic seems to have also hit the country as the number of cases started to increase in the last few months. The government of Somaliahas eased most of the restrictions in August 2020 and most of the public services have resumed. This increases the risk of vulnerability to COVID-19 and the shortages of water in many areas further restrict the communities' ability to frequently wash their hands with soap. This might create a favourable environment for COVID-19 to spread.
The Ministry of Water Development in Somaliland shareda request with all humanitarian agencies, indicating that over 196,848 people are in need of urgent water interventions and that many others also require quick rehabilitations of their water sources. Over 88% of the people in need are from the Sool, Sanaag, and Togdheer regions of Eastern Somaliland. In October 2020, Oxfam using the ECHO crisis modifier budget reached the most vulnerable 1,800 HH (10,800 people) in Sool, Sanaag, and Togdheer for 30 days with WASH interventions. Since then, we have continued to advocate for urgent interventions by sharing summary reports with the Somalia WASH cluster and presentations of the situation with cluster members. Utilising other existing resources, we are also working with the Ministry of Water Resources to rehabilitate boreholes that were identified as strategic wells by the government.

title: Innovative Fishery Development
description:
The first component is aimed at capacity building. At least 40 beneficiaries (at least 30% female) including fishermen and women, fishmongers will undergo a maximum of six months theoretical and practical training. Youth fishermen and women will be trained on safety at sea, fishing gear mending and repairs, safe fishing methods and fish preservation, cooperatives establishment and fish quality assurance. Fishmongers, who will mostly be women, will be trained in various topics including fish handling and preservation, fishprocessing, personal hygiene, value addition (processing, grading, and packaging) and small business management. Entrepreneurship will be an integral part of the courses in order to leverage the entrepreneurship capacity
The second component is aimed at supporting the establishment/ strengthening of fishery organizations. The target beneficiaries will be organized in Self Help Groups (SHGs). The SHG is a rights-based approach which views poverty as the denial of rights and poverty alleviation as a process of reclaiming one’s rights. Given the multi-dimensional nature of poverty, the SHG Approach puts equal emphasis on the goals of economic, social andpolitical empowerment . Therefore, the established/strengthened SHGs will have the potential to empower small-scale fishers againstsome of the environmental and socioeconomic shocks such as fish catch shortfalls and revenues, sickness and death in their families, natural disasters and hunger. The 30 young fishermen will be organized intoat least 5 SHGs and will be trained/ oriented on the operations of the SHGs
The third component will support the distribution of fishing kits/gear to the SHGs including women fishmongers.Midway through the training, the project beneficiaries will be provided with fishing gears in their SGHs. Such gear may include boats and other necessary tools. On the other hand, women fishmongers, will have business start-up kits including refrigerators and basic fish processing tools. The fishing kits/ gear will be owned and managed jointly in the SHGs.
The fourth component will focus on learning and knowledge management through value chain research. In order to ensure systematic market mapping in the fishing sector, understand actors, market share, capacity gaps, and other relevant value chain information, the project will undertake a robust research on fish value chain. The research will aim to bring out suitable models to link small holders to input and output markets and improve the benefits that fishermen and women and other resource-poor value chain actors derive from the chain. Knowledge generated from the research will be disseminated to different relevant stakeholders in the sector. It will also act as a building block for future scaling efforts of the project. As Oxfam and the partner have both long-term livelihood strategies, the research finding would beused for future programing.

title: Strengthening  Capacity of Nexus Members
description:
Somalia, a fragile State that is emerging from decades of civil war, is currently experiencing an unprecedented situation mainly caused by climate change, Covid-19 and locust infestation, which exacerbated the long-term existed challenges within the country including widespread vulnerability and marginalization, insecurity and government with poor institutional capacity to deliver and advocate for basic humanitarian needs of local communities, combination of the above mentioned challenges contributed to negative socio-economic impact on Somali communities and resulted in the displacement of affected populations (mainly rural) and formation of IDP sites alongside main towns.
Other challenges encountered by Somalia and Somaliland communities include lack of coping capacity to climate change and widespread dependency created by Humanitarian Aid due to the absence of government’s role that affects the livelihood of entire communities rather than building their long-term resilience. It's evident that the Humanitarian Aid Dependency has largely affected the productivity of the Somali population. However, there's need to exhaust to what extent these will be addressed by our research questions for the Participatory Action Research (PAR) on Aid Humanitarian Aid dependency.
In 2019, nine Somali NGOs founded the Nexus platform that aims to shape the future in Somalia and Somaliland, by creating an enabling environment for Somali NGOs to have a leading role in the humanitarian system that puts the agency and self-reliance of communities at the center, through delivering a combination of Humanitarian Aid, Development, and Peace interventions. The Nexus coalition is led by nine Somali NGOs – African Development Solutions (ADESO), Centre for Peace and Democracy (CPD), Gargaar Relief and Development Organization (GREDO), Horn of Africa Voluntary Youth Committee (HAVOYOCO), KAALO, Save Somali Women and Children (SSWC), Social-Life and Agriculture Development Organisation (SADO), Taakulo Somaliland Community (TASCO), and WASDA. Two INGOs – Oxfam and Save the Children International were invited to join as international partners to support with critical investments.
So far the platform developed and applied its strategy andtheory of change whilst Humanitarian actions are the platform’s immediate priority in its current scope of work, Somalia Nexus consortium aims to focus interventions that are in line with its pillars, including Community-driven and working across the Triple Nexusof Development, Humanitarian Aid, Peace-building and conflict-resolution, as well as strengthening the capacity of Somali Civil Society <(>&<)> Government institutions. In addition, special considerations will be given concerning practicality and implementation methodology including presence, scaleof the need, duration and coordination with other stakeholders.
The day-to-day activities of theplatform are performed by the Secretariat supported by the Steering committee who are also responsible for resource mobilization, organizing coordination meetings, fund management and drafting policies and guidelines
In 2021, the Nexus platform aims to implement efforts to support its members and government institutions in both Somalia and Somaliland, through development of Community-driven Development manuals, conducting Participatory Action Research that finds durable solutions on climate related challenges in both pastoral and agro-pastoral communities, conducting PAR that aims to address the level and scope of dependency created by Unconditional Cash disbursement to local rural communities as well as supporting Somalia and Somaliland governments to develop standardized Cash Transfer model with clear guidelines.
Social inclusion, protection and Covid-19 protocols will be maintained and mainstreamed in project interventions.

title: CO-WASH Innovation Fund
description:
COVID19 disease has been identified in China and later declared as a global pandemic by WHO on March 11, 2020. In Somalia and Somaliland, the first case of the disease was reported in March 2020, and since then, the government authorities implemented measures including movement restrictions, banning all community gathering, closing schools and other religious facilities. Somalia has over three million internally displaced communities (OCHA, Somalia) and over 79% of Somalis are living either below or near the internationalpoverty line (NDP-9, Somalia). The majority of IDPs live in overcrowded settlements with weakened infrastructure, insufficient access to WASH facilities and inaccessible health services. Since later last year, the locust manifestation and floods destroyed majority posture and farmland deteriorating the already weakened communities.
Somalia is one of the worst prepared countries in the world to contain the disease. WHO recommends the use of personal protective equipment, frequent handwashing and social distance to contain COVID19. Oxfam Somalia works with communities to promote these critical measures and raise awareness of communities on COVID19. Thissupport requires a close engagement with communities and health volunteers. However, since the first COVID19 case was declared in Somalia, we have limited our community contact and tried to see possible options to provide Real-time support to our communities. This included using a mobile-based application, Well Beyond, to provide COVID19 prevention and containment training. This trail was found to be effective and efficient. We are now proposing the scale up the same approach to expand to include other training including hygiene promotions, WASHCO training, WASH <(>&<)> Protection related training.
COVID19 has changed our traditional ways of living, working and our regular ways of implementing programs. For ownership and sustainability, it is critical to ensure communities' involvement in program design and implementation. In COVID19 environment, this can only be possible by using technologies to deliver training, information and collect feedback.
We wish to deploy critically needed information into the Oxfam Somalia regions of work through the Well Beyond App. This life-saving mobile technology sends interactive COVID-19 and Sanitation and Hygiene training material tothe community based health voluneteers. The technology will fill knowledge gap between COVID-19 recommendations and the tools and knowledge available in the remote, rural places. It serve by providing vital training material, guidance on handwashing stations, surface hygiene, sanitation and real-time chat support, and other tools to help communities prevent the spread of COVID-19. At the sametime, Oxfam Somalia will be able to track training completions and collect data on the solution’s success. This will allow the Oxfam field team to continuously interact with our beneficiaries and community health volunteers.

The UN Economic Commission for Africaprojected more than hundreds of thousands of Africans could lose their lives due to COVID-19. The Somali government, in alignment with the WHO, emphasizes that basic, preventative measures by individuals and communities remain the most powerful tool to prevent the spread of COVID-19, but delivering this critical information has been a challenge, as the movement within countries is very limited, and social distancing guidelines prohibit large group trainings in person. The Well Beyond App will allow us to provide this crucial guidance to our CHVs and support to our communities, even though we aren’t physically able to be there.

title: CO-Rapid Assessment CFM
description:
Oxfam’s commitment is to actively centre the voice and experience of people and community in all our work and consider power, privilege and equity in the design of community-based feedback and complaints mechanisms CBFCMS, and to respect the knowledge, wisdom andperspective of others, as there is always scope for Oxfam to grow and learn as an organisation working with communities.
Functionalfeedback and complaints mechanisms that are accessible and safe to use are a demonstration of our organization-wide accountability commitment, to be truly accountable to the people and communities we work with and those affected by our programmes, by ensuring that they understand what is appropriate and inappropriate conduct of our staff and partners, getting their feedback about our programmes and/or complaints about conduct of our staff, agents or partners  and taking appropriate action to address these concerns. Accountability is “the process of using power responsibly, taking account of, and being held accountable by different stakeholders, and primarily those who are affected by the exercise of such power” . It is the right to be heard, and the duty to respond.

However, anecdotal information indicates that where CBFCMs initiatives and experiences exist in Oxfam, many are still disjointed, some are uncoordinated, and largely undocumented. In many places, they are non-existent, or if they are, not all of them are fully functional. The design of Oxfam’s CBFCMs by Affiliates, Country Offices and in part Partners has not always ensured community involvement, in most cases resulting in not fit for purpose mechanisms. Also different affiliates still approach the issue of CBFCMs differently with different emphasis, approaches, tools and resources, therefore lacking a standardised coordinated approach.

Although Oxfam prides itself for encouraging communities we work with to speak out and report PSEA and child protection concerns and incidents concerning them,recent reports in some countries like DRC, Ethiopia, and Uganda not only attests to the limited awareness at community level on SEAand child protection risks and reporting mechanisms, but has also led to an increase in attention to ensure that SEA and child abuse and exploitation by humanitarian and development organisations like Oxfam are addressed through investment in preventive approaches but also responding to reports of abuse and exploitation when these incidents are reported.
Oxfam has two responsibilities for accountability in the programmes it manages, holding a responsibility for mutual accountability with its partners (as do the partners) and also holding a shared or joint accountability (with its partners) to the communities affected by its programmes. There is lack of knowledge how the
In addition to some of the above challenges, COVID-19 has added additional challenges to how effective current CBFCMs are, placing additional barriers to reporting that are currently not fully understood or risks mitigated.
OBJECTIVES OF THE PROJECT:
1. Map out existing CBCM’s initiatives in select field/project locations, and document best practices and lessons learnt in implementing CBFCMs across the Oxfam confederation
2. Undertake a rapid assessment of the existing CBFCMs in Oxfam terms of effectiveness, experiences and lessons plus existing gaps.

title: Supporting on Borehole Drill  in Somalia
description:
The eastern regions in Somaliland and especially Saanag and Sool regions continue to suffer from recurrent drought. This situation has increased the vulnerability of the communities as they have lost most of their livestock which was their main source oflivelihood. The situation is exacerbated by the fact that the two regions also continue to experience occasional inter clan fighting which isoften triggered by competition for available pasture and water resources. Drilling of the a boreholes will not only contribute to providing important water sources that can support the water needs of the communities during drought and harsh climatic conditions, but also contribute to reducing risk factors leading to conflict. It will offer an opportunity to the benefiting communities to have a chance for better access to potable water, reduce the incidents water related diseases and increase access for water for practicing frequent handwashing to prevent COVID-19.
Objectives;
• Provide sustainable water source for 5000 people and over 10,000 livestockheads in Sanaag Region.
Groundwater Feasibility Study:
A groundwater feasibility study will be conducted in three selected villagesof Sanaag region. the study will follow three approach method,
1. Remote Sensing: Desk review using latest satellite imageries to selected best possible locations. This phase will focus on finding regional fractures carrying water from highland of Ethiopia to thelowland of Sanaag regions and from Sanaag mountains to low land areas.
2. Geophysical Study: ground truthing work will be conducting using latest start of art geophysical technology at least three locations with spacing of 1000 -1500m. This location are those selected in first phase of the study work. Government and community engagement will be conducted to understand the local geology, possible impact of drilling on environment and stability of the communities.
Drilling of the borehole
Based on the groundwater feasibility study, the drilling work will be advertised through the local media. In order to avoid failures resulted from improper use of drilling equipment and selection of drilling method, the contractor will receive full copy of the study report and will be given a briefing on the drilling technology and technique recommended by the study team. Then, a payment by result approach will be used to contract drilling companies i.e. Oxfam/Taakulo will only pay if the borehole has water with discharge of above 2liter per second. Failureto get a contractor willing to commence drilling with such conduction, further meeting will be help between Oxfam and Taakulo to discuss best possible approach to increase value for money.
Supervision and Monitoring:
In drilling works supervision and monitoring progress is critical step. Oxfam/Taakulo will have a site supervisor equipped with necessary materials for supervision including TDS Sensor to record water quality at each 1 meter, mud funnel to record the drilling mud viscosity and deeper to follow the depth of the drilling. The supervisor will provide daily update to both Oxfam/Taakulo team and will ensure all decision that affect drilling performance is consulted and agreed before action. TDS level will be recorded in monitoring tool provided and the result will be used for deciding the borehole casing arrangement. All materials that will be used for drilling will be inspected by the drilling supervisor and approve. In case a specialized chemical will be used for the drilling; the supervisor will request for all safety related certificate prior use of such chemicals.
Post Drilling Construction:
This action will be decided right after the drilling is completed. Provision of submersible pump with cable and riser pipes, and construction of generator house, water distribution system for both animal and human and storage facilities will be included under this phase. Other grants, including ECHO 2021 and/or other internal grants will be used to finance this critical activity. Incase the borehole salinity is above an acceptable regional level i.e. 2500ppm, provision of desalination unit will be considered.

title: Support to WHO EMRO
description: to support personnel and activities that will work to interrupt the transmission of polio virus

title: Repositioning polio eradication efforts
description: to focus on re-positioning polio eradication efforts in Islamic countries so that it is perceived as a local activity, addresses community concerns and strengthens local ownership and visibility

title: Strengthening EMRO Regional and Country Polio Operations
description: to interrupt wild poliovirus transmission in Eastern Mediterranean Region by conducting activities in the endemic country of Afghanistan as well as those affected by outbreaks

title: Research Activities in Support of the Global Polio Eradication Initiative
description: to fund research projects at the World Health Organization in support of the Global Polio Eradication Initiative 2015-2018

title: Conflict Prevention and Peacebuilding Programme
description: This Programme is made up of three pillars: 1) Strengthen access to justice systems and capacities of community members (rights holders) and local authorities (duty bearers) to prevent and manage conflicts (or disputes) in a non-violent way that aligns with international protection standards in 2 districts in Benadir Region of Somalia. 2) Contribute to strengthening resilience, well-being and inclusive participation of conflict-affected Bantu and Twa through peacebuilding and conflict prevention initiatives in Nyunzu and Kalemie Health Zones in Tanganyika Province, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. 3) The programme’s Learning and Coordination Component will develop a learning framework to determine whether the program’s theory of change holds, through which mechanisms, and under which conditions. The main area of research and learning will be changes in access to services (access to health facilities in DRC and access to justice in Somalia) and how this contributes to conflict prevention and to inclusive peacebuilding processes. This pillar is managed from the UK. Please note: when funds are allocated to the UK this is to the general benefit of all IRC Programmes and the wider sector.

title: DFID Somalia Social Norms and Participation Programme (SNAP): Challenging Harmful Attitudes and Norms for Gender Equality and Empowerment in Somalia (CHANGES)
description: In response to DFID Somalias Call for Proposals, Save the Children, in consortium with International Rescue Committee and CARE International, will implement a range of interventions which will be Challenging Harmful Attitudes and Norms for Gender Equality and Empowerment in Somalia (CHANGES). The proposed project seeks to challenge harmful social norms including Female Genital Mutilation and Child Early and Forced Marriage and to increase womens social and economic empowerment through interventions at the individual, household, community and societal levels. Successful implementation of these interventions will result in reduction in harmful practices, increased value of women and girls and will contribute towards greater voice, choice and control for Somali women and girls over their bodies and futures (Project Impact). This will be achieved transforming social norms to support gender equality in Somalia (Outcome) through three key outcome areas: 1) Enhanced legal and policy environment for greater equality of women and girls; 2) Improved knowledge and attitudes of men, women, girls and boys on gender discriminatory social norms; and 3) Increased social and economic empowerment of women and girls. IRC will be working in Galkayo (South), Hobyo, Hawal-wadag, Karaan.

implementing: Mudug Peace and Human Development Organization (MPHDO)
Mudug Peace and Humanitarian Development Organization
Mudug Peace and Human Development Organisation

title: Somalia Humanitarian and Resilience Program (SHARP)
description: As a follow up to BRCIS1, The BRCiS Consortium will use adaptive management and community-designed and led solutions to build resilience to local shocks and stresses. It focuses on reinforcing social cohesion and natural resource management capacities, fostering economic opportunities, and enabling access to basic services through approaches that adapt to learning, changing contexts, and community-driven priorities. DFID has confirmed a total of GBP 16 million to the BRCiS consortium to support this project.

identifier: US-EIN-521257057-NDC Partnership Support Unit and CAEP/TAF
title: NDC Partnership Support Unit and CAEP - BEIS
description: The NDC Partnership (the Partnership) is a global coalition of countries and institutions collaborating to drive transformational climate action while enhancing sustainable development. The Partnership is working directly with developing country governments, mobilizing resources and expertise to support and accelerate their Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC) implementation and increased ambition in updated NDC around the worlds. The Partnership is recognized as a neutral broker among stakeholders and a trusted partner, evidencing a strong governance structure, clear theory of change, and transparent strategy. Guided by a Steering Committee, the Partnership is comprised of developed and developing nations and international institutions and led by Co-Chairs from the Republic of Costa Rica and the Kingdom of the Netherlands. A Support Unit, which facilitates the work of the Partnership, has grown and consolidated to support its ambitious vision. As more governments seek support for turning NDCs into action, membership continues to grow considerably.

title: 2020 CRRP - Desert Locust Crisis Response in Ethiopia, Kenya, Somalia, Uganda, Djibouti, and Eritrea
description:
The worst desert locust crisis in decades is underway in the Greater Horn of Africa, where hundreds of thousands of hectares of cropland and pasture have been damaged. The infestation will create considerable risk on the economic livelihoods of smallholder farmers, including those we are seeking to support through our Young Africa Works programs. The agricultural sector represents over 50 percent of our Young Africa Works programs. 
Specifically, FAO has requested $10M (total budget $138M) from the Foundation to assist with: 
1.	Early detection through systematic monitoring, enabling stronger decision-making process for ground and aerial control operations.
2.	Ground and aerial control to reduce the locust population, mainly through spraying pesticides. 
3.	Conducting an impact assessment and promoting environment, health, and safety measures for safe pesticide use and management.

title: Somaliland (Somalia) Programme
description: This programme aims to provide Security and Justice Sector Reform by increasing civilian oversight and professionalisation of the Somaliland Army and Coastguard. Increasing the effectiveness and accountability of the Judiciary and Prosecutors through development of the Somaliland High Judicial Council, and improving court security and administration Increasing the capacity of the Somaliland Police to provide security in an effective and human rights compliant manner and improving human resource and financial management. This is an ODA and non-ODA integrated programme. The spend reported against this programme is the ODA element alone.

title: Somalia Counter Extremism Programme
description: This programme aims to support the Federal Government of Somalia to implement its National Programme for treatment and handling of disengaged combatants, designed to incentivise defections from Al Shabaab by providing alternative paths and viable rehabilitation options. This programme included Covid-19 activity in FY 20/21 Q1.

title: Somalia Security Sector Reform Programme
description: This programme aims to strengthen Somalia’s security institutions and governance at the national and regional level and reinforcing effective linkages between them; supporting AMISOM in delivering effective operations through capacity building. Improving the capacity of Somalia’s police force through training and capacity building. This is an ODA and non-ODA integrated programme. The spend reported against this programme is the ODA element alone. This programme included Covid-19 activity in FY 20/21 Q1.

title: Somalia Stabilisation Programme
description: This programme aims to reduce local drivers of conflict in areas of Somalia recently recovered from al-Shabaab control and provide foundations for the local political settlements and stability that will allow the Federal Government of Somalia and Federal Member States to establish a sustained presence. The programme also aims to deliver improved community cohesion through inclusive community engagement and a set of upstream interventions with both local and international actors to enhance civil-military coordination and influence Somalia’s overall approach to early recovery stabilisation. This programme included Covid-19 activity in FY 20/21 Q1.

title: Supporting Inclusive Growth in Somalia (SIGS)
description: SIGS programme is the UK’s flagship economic development programme in Somalia.  Designed as a flexible and adaptive programme it will provide an immediate response to Covid19. It now has a stronger focus on remittances, supporting UK political leadership in this area, and, accelerated support to key Micro, Small and Medium Sized Enterprise (MSME) sectors including domestic food production and marketing.  SIGS will deliver activities to  1.	Develop and diversify businesses in approx. 4 high-value sectors. 2.	Stimulate investment through developing the financial sector and related policy and or regulatory capacity.  3.	Develop the evidence base on inclusive, sustainable, economic development in Somalia.   SIGS will provide an essential policy and influencing resource for UK leadership on HIPC debt relief and or the associated reforms, including on the financial sector and counter terrorist financing.

title: Support to Aid Coordination and Effectiveness in Somalia
description: To improve international aid delivery to Somalia, making it more coordinated, accountable and effective in meeting the needs of the Somali people. UK support will contribute to: a more inclusive, effective and efficient aid architecture; strengthened national ownership and capacity for aid coordination processes and better coherence in the international community’s support for aid coordination and effectiveness. Streamlined processes and increased transparency will support more strategic allocation of resources and improved coordination of effort across the international community. This will also contribute to SDGs 1, 16 and 17 by strengthening institutions to progressively deliver universal access to basic services. The UK played a leading role in the development of Somalia’s aid architecture and has a strong interest in providing an effective platform for coordinated and sustained levels of long-term support for Somalia.

description: Somalia Stability Fund III will work to build stability in Somalia. It will do so by deepening understanding of the core underlying causes and drivers of conflict and instability.  It will address them in ways that help widen and deepen the political settlement (agreements between different political actors), at multiple levels, and help build resilience to conflict and violence when these political settlement processes inevitably come under stress.

title: Integrating Sexual and Reproductive Health Services in Bosaso
description: The programme through a contribution to Médecins du Monde-France aims at improving access to sexual and reproductive health (SRH) services for the population of Bosaso (Puntland, Somalia). This will be done through progressively integrating the SRH into existing primary health care services offered in health facilities. Regional health authorities as well as local health providers are closely involved in the intervention to not only ensure that services are culturally responsive but also that they become an integral part of the health system.

title: Humanitarian mine action in Somalia NL MFA 2020-2024
description: The target groups for this project are communities suffering from the threat of landmines and other explosive remnants of war in Somalia. The target group for the capacity building is the Somali Explosive Management Authority (SEMA).

title: 3. Mine Action and Cluster Munitions Programme 2016 -2020
description: Somalia is in the process of transitioning from a 'failed' to a 'fragile' state with central and recognised governemental institutions. To date, the country remains divided by various political and clan factions and strong anti-governement elements who are benefiting from the availability remnants or war (ERW) such as landmines and unexploded ordinance (UXO) thereby significantly weakening the overall stability and security in Somalia. This project seeks to reduce the impact of landmines, unsecured ammunition stockpiles, UXO and other ERW have at regional level. Phase one will target Northern Somalia (Somaliland) where large clearance efforts are coming to an end in the next three years and where, until clerarance is completed, accidents will continue to affect rural communities. HALO will deploy four manual clerance teams and one mechanical team to clear 616,000m2 from 1 Setember 2016 to 31 December 2018. Phase two will take place in Southern Somalia where government credibility has been gradualy increasing and where making concrete steps to restore stability can significantly foster state's legitimacy. International funding for HMA in Somalia is contributing to the multilateral effort to stabilise Southern Somalia by addressing factors leading Somali populations to migrate to Europe in search of better futures. HALO’s work in Southern Somalia began in 2015, and a process of slow, steady development is being undertaken to minimize risks to the programme.

reported_by: Direction-Générale Coopération au Développement et Aide humanitaire
title: Action Humanitaire pour les Enfants (Nigeria, Somalie, Soudan du Sud, Syrie)
description:
Output 1: Access and utilization of quality integrated basic primary health care (PHC) services improved among the general population with emphasis on children under five, youth, women and other vulnerable groups in conflict affected settlements in Borno State.
Output 2: 500,000 people have sustained access to safe water in IDP camps and host communities
Output 3: 500,000 people have sustained access to gender-segregated improved sanitation facilities in IDP camps. The overall objective with this funding is to contribute to the realization of UNICEF’s planned humanitarian support in north eastern Nigeria by providing access to WASH and integrated PHC services to affected populations by the ongoing conflict.  Improve resilience of the population affected by the northeast insurgency through reduced morbidity and mortality. Output 1.1: Pregnant and lactating women have access to Basic Emergency Obstetric and neonatal care (antenatal care, skilled birth deliveries, postnatal care, newborn care) and referral of complicated cases. 
Output 1.2: Children under-5 and women have access to promotive and preventive services (including immunization) at both community and health facility levels.
Output 2.1:  Improved, integrated, quality basic nutrition services for children and PLW, including IDPs, are available.
Output 2.2:  Individuals, households and communities have improved knowledge of essential nutrition behaviours and increased capacity to plan manage and monitor recurrent shocks and stresses.
Output 3: 56,400 people affected by drought, conflict and other emergencies provided with access to safe water supply and improved sanitation services. This project will provide a package of life-saving integrated interventions for women and children affected by conflict and acute malnutrition in South Central Somalia, Somaliland and Puntland regions, as well as IDP settlements. Through this project, UNICEF will provide integrated interventions through fixed and mobile outreach to enable communities to access quality primary health care, nutrition and WASH services and build resilience against repeated shocks. Objective 1: Reduced morbidity and mortality from maternal and child health-related conditions amongst targeted IDP and host community populations. 
Objective 2: Treatment of 5,000 children affected by life threatening SAM in northern regions of Somalia.
Objective 3: Provision of a comprehensive package of nutrition promotional and preventative services for 9,200 children under 5 years and 2,300 pregnant and lactating women (PLW). 
Objective 4: Provision of gender responsive and protection sensitive access to WASH services for 56,400 people in areas affected by drought and other emergencies. Output 1: 12,500 affected people provided with basic WASH supplies 
Output 1.2: 3125 people (25 per cent of those provided with basic WASH supplies) reached with basic access to water, supply and sanitation. 
Output 2: 5,000 extremely vulnerable children reached with CPiE and CAAC interventions that are in line with child protection minimum standards. Twelve thousand five hundred (12,500) affected people will be provided with basic WASH supplies and 3125 people will also be reached with basic access to water, supply and sanitation. Five thousand (5,000) extremely vulnerable children (including children associated with armed forces and groups (CAAFAG)), identified as at high risk of violence, abuse, neglect and exploitation, in South Sudan will access Child Protection in Emergencies (CPiE) services to address specific protection needs and build resilience. Improved emergency WASH promotion services for conflict affected people, vulnerable host communities and people in disease prone areas.

Improved protection and well-being for children conflict-affected areas. Output 1: Boys and girls have Improved psychosocial well-being and resilience through community-based child protection mechanisms to prevention and response to violence against children.

Output 2: Boys and girls affected by armed conflict in Syria have improved access to specialized child protection services  including cash transfer for children with severe disabilities. 

Output 3:  Capacities of child protection actors and services providers social workers strengthened to better protect vulnerable children from abuse, violence and exploitation in targeted locations.

Output 4: Boys, girls, men and women in targeted areas benefit from information and prevention messages to reduce the impact of explosive ordnance hazards. Increase an equitable access for boys and girls to quality child protection interventions in targeted locations in line with the Child Protection Minimum Standards in Humanitarian Action.

title: Reducing HIV infections and HIV related mortality among Somalis
description: Somalia - HIV - United Nations Children's Fund - UNICEF.  This program has the following goals: By 2023, reduce the rate of new infections by 30%.  By 2023, reduce HIV related mortality and morbidity for Somali women, men and children by 30%. The objectives of this program are: By 2023 increase the percentage of people living with HIV who know their HIV status to over 75%.  By 2023, increase the percentage of other vulnerable populations who have received a HIV test during the reporting period to 80%.  By 2023, increase the percentage of people on ART among all people living with HIV to over 46%.  By 2023, increase the percentage of people living with HIV on ART who are virologically suppressed to 89%.  By 2023, increase the percentage of people living with HIV who are newly initiated on ART screened for TB to 85%.  By 2023, reduce the rate percentage of people living with HIV who report experiences of HIV-related discrimination in health-care settings to 30% or below.

title: Maximizing efforts to control and eliminate Malaria in Somalia
description: Somalia - Malaria - United Nations Children's Fund - UNICEF.  This program has the following goals: Ensure there is interruption of local Plasmodium falciparum transmission in 25% of the regions.  Prepare 50% of regions for pre-elimination (malaria incidence <1 case per 1000) in which there has been historically low transmission.  Reduce malaria case morbidity and mortality by 40% in endemic areas. The objectives of this program are: To consolidate the achievements of the previous NSPs.  To maintain and increase equitable coverage of interventions for all at risk populations including internally displaced persons (IDPs) and mobile populations where geographically relevant.  To enhance national surveillance systems and community based case management to promote an enabling environment in which to move towards malaria elimination in areas of continually low transmission.

title: Reducing TB incidence and TB related mortality among Somalis
description: Somalia - Tuberculosis.  This program has the following goals: 50% reduction in TB deaths (compared with 2015).  30% reduction in TB incidence rate (compared with 2015).  >20% affected families facing catastrophic costs. The objectives of this program are: To increase case detection, and ensure treatment completion of all forms of notified drug susceptible TB cases from 16,918 in 2019 to 27,000 by 2023, while increasing the treatment success rate from 86% in 2017 to 90% by 2023.  To increase the number of RR/MDR TB cases enrolled on treatment from 335 in 2019 to 1044 in 2023 while increasing the treatment success rate from 79% in the cohort of 2016 to >85% in the cohort of 2021.  To ensure all diagnosed TB patients are tested for HIV and are aware about their HIV status. In addition, increase the proportion of TB/HIV coinfected patients on ART to > 90% by 2023 from existing 72% in 2019.  NTP program management capacities improved at all levels (coordination, monitoring and evaluation, data collection and exploitation for planning, execution of operational research.  The proportion of patients (children under five, HIV patients without TB disease, respectively) initiated on TPT increased to 80% in 2024.
